headline: <p>The under-35s are bearing the brunt of the jobs crisis<p>
content: <p>According to official figures
column5: younger people continue to bear the brunt of the jobs crisis.<p><p>80% of the 811
column6: 000 payroll jobs lost in the UK in the year to March were under the age of 35.<p><p>The unemployment rate was 4.9% in the three months to February
column7: down from 5% previously.<p><p>This was despite the fact that most of the UK was locked down.<p><p>The jobs market remains subdued
column8: with five million people employed but still on the unemployment line
column9: according to the ONS.<p><p>The head of economics at the British Chambers of Commerce
column10: Surenx80 Thiru
column11: said that unemployment will peak at the end of 2021.<p><p>The longer-term structural unemployment caused by Covid-19
column12: particularly among young people
column13: may mean that the road back to pre-pandemic levels lags behind the wider economic recovery.<p><p>Between December and February
column14: 1.67 million people were out of work.That is down from the previous quarter but still higher than a year ago.<p><p>The retail and hospitality sectors were hit hard by the crisis
column15: and younger people are suffering disproportionately.<p><p>Most of the payroll jobs lost in the year to March were held by people under the age of 35.<p><p>The number of young people in employment has hit a "post-pandemic low" according to Gerwyn Davies.<p><p>The urgent case for apprenticeship incentives to be made more generous is reinforced by this.It would be wrong to get carried away with the pleasant surprise of a dip in the official unemployment rate below 5%.<p><p>The tax data for March shows the true picture of the disease.The fact that the numbers in the first few months have been stable is definitely a source of relief.Thanks to the extension of support schemes
column16: employers were able to navigate the second lockdown without a lot of job losses.<p><p>As support is phased out in late summer
column17: there will be strains.<p><p>Hope of a lower peak to unemployment is offered by these figures.The jobs market has been stable in recent months
column18: according to the ONS.The labour market remains subdued but there are positive signs.<p><p>The recovery still depends on the evolution of the Pandemic
column19: according to an economist.<p><p>If the government\'s plan to reopen the economy continues
column20: we expect a gradual recovery in the labour market in the coming months.<p>

headline: <p>Finding work feels impossible for my generation<p>
content: <p>"During Covid
column5: job seeking has felt impossible
column6: leaving her low and close to despair.<p><p>According to new research from the Prince's Trust
column7: people under the age of 25 account for three in five of the jobs lost during the crisis so far.<p><p>The problem is that younger workers are over-represented in sectors hit hardest by the Pandemic and these will take longer to recover.<p><p>Because I want to work in the creative industries
column8: there is almost nothing out there - the industry has been.<p><p>A lot of jobs require experience
column9: but how are you supposed to get it if it isn't given to you?<p><p>The Prince's Trust says long term changes in the labour market will make it harder for.<p><p>Over the next seven years
column10: it expects the lost earnings and damaged employment prospects to cost the jobseekers as much as Â£14.4 billion.<p><p>Matthew Gilbert graduated from Reading University last year and has been looking for a job.<p><p>It has caused a lot of stress.<p><p>It has made me feel like I don't have a direction and it is slowly grinding down my confidence
column11: says Mr Gilbert
column12: who lives with his parents on London.He is looking for work in ecology and wildlife preservation
column13: but he says a lot of candidates are chasing a small number of jobs.<p><p>Since March of last year
column14: he has only been asked about four times.<p><p>He has faced issues with mental health and anxiety
column15: but he tries to stay positive.<p><p>If youth unemployment remains high for a long time
column16: the Prince's Trust warns
column17: pre-existing inequalities could get worse.<p><p>It says the decline in working hours for young people with no qualifications has been five times higher than the decline for those with a degree level qualification.<p><p>Failing to take action risks not only harming young people's futures
column18: but the future of our economy as a whole.<p><p>The Youth Offer includes access to support from our Youth Hubs and Kickstart
column19: which has already created 150
column20: 000 approved job placements.We are helping young people get the skills they need as we build back better.<p><p>Are you a young person without a job?If you are willing to speak to a journalist
column21: please email haveyoursay@hello.co.uk.<p><p>You can reach out in a number of ways."<p>

headline: <p>The economic outlook is usually uncertain<p>
content: <p>The Bank of England said the outlook for the UK economy was "unusually uncertain" despite the rapid roll out of the vaccine programme.<p><p>Everyone above the age of 50 will have their first jab by the end of May
column5: followed by everyone by the end of July.<p><p>The governor of the Bank of England said last week that he expected the economy to come back at the end of the year.<p><p>The Office for Budget Responsibility predicts that unemployment will peak at 6.5% instead of the 11.9% predicted last July.<p><p>However
column6: an official statement on Thursday from the Bank\'s Monetary Policy Committee
column7: which sets interest rates
column8: was more cautious.<p><p>The outlook for the UK economy
column9: and particularly the relative movement in demand and supply during the recovery from the recession
column10: was unclear.<p><p>The cross-currents are the same for the Bank of England.<p><p>Since its previous meeting in February
column11: most developments - notably fresh rounds of fiscal stimuli domestically and abroad - have had positive implications for the economic outlook
column12: but downside risks and uncertainty concerning the evolution of the pandemic are still prominent.<p><p>The monetary policy committee had no immediate plans to tighten monetary policy.<p><p>The committee stands ready to take whatever action is necessary to achieve its objectives if the outlook for inflation weakens.<p><p>The risk of a rate rise is downplayed in today\'s Monetary Policy Report.<p><p>There is more than one reason for the BoE to do so.<p><p>Weird things have come to many of our lives.<p><p>The Bank of England is the same.<p><p>It insists it doesn\'t engage in monetary financing
column13: where the central bank simply creates money from nothing (once upon a time you could say "prints money" but now it\'s digital) and "lends" it to the government.<p><p>What\'s happening now isn\'t much different.According to the Financial Times
column14: almost all of the money being borrowed by the government this financial year will be owed to the Bank of England.<p><p>The government borrows most of its money from another branch of the public sector.<p><p>It gets it back if it pays interest on the debt.<p><p>It\'s easy to make money.<p><p>The money the BoE creates from nothing is used to buy gilts from big City players
column15: hoping they\'ll invest the cash in productive industry.<p><p>BoE reserves pay interest at the official rate.The BoE would be the biggest loser if rates rose.<p>

headline: <p>The Bank of England is considering a digital money plan<p>
content: <p>"The aim is to look at the risks and opportunities involved in creating a new kind of digital money.Issued by the Bank for use by households and The Bank sees having its own digital currency as a way of avoiding the risks of new forms of private money creation.<p><p>Cash and bank deposits would not be replaced with anyCBDC.<p><p>The Bank of England has been talking about digital currencies.<p><p>An alternative digital currency will be looked into by the Treasury and it will be used by households and businesses.<p><p>This year has seen the flotation of Coinbase and the stellar performance of various cryptocurrencies.<p><p>The plumbing of the financial system could be changed by a digital version of sterling backed by the Bank of England.<p><p>It wouldn't be like a speculative asset with wild fluctuations in value.<p><p>There will be limited appeal for fans who invest because of their skepticism about central banks.The direct relationship that ordinary citizens might have with the central bank could be revolutionary.<p><p>Simple
column5: direct means of stimulating the economy could be used.<p><p>In theory
column6: central banks would know when and where e-cash transactions took place.<p><p>China is ahead of the game when it comes to digital yuan experiments.<p><p>Ensuring that the UK remains at the forefront of financial innovation is part of the rationale.<p><p>Most of the world's central banks are looking into the possibility of creating such a currency
column7: but the only one already in existence is China's digital yuan
column8: which is currently undergoing public testing."<p>

headline: <p>The shoppers come back to High Street<p>
content: <p>After non-essential stores reopened in England and Wales
column5: shoppers went back to the High Street to treat themselves.<p><p>Springboard said footfall was up 87.8% across all UK shopping destinations.<p><p>Visitor numbers and sales have gone up at more than 60 shops.<p><p>People were splashing out after being unable to go shopping.<p><p>Anna said there was a lot of that.People were spending and treating themselves because they\'ve probably saved money
column6: because they saw online that people weren\'t going away
column7: they were getting refunds and were spending and treating themselves.<p><p>"Now I think there are still limitations to what people can do
column8: and I think they\'re thinking they\'ve always wanted that Swiss watch or that diamond ring
column9: and they are just treating themselves
column10: which is brilliant to see."Springboard said footfall across High Streets
column11: retail parks and The demand was greatest in the East Midlands
column12: South East and South West.<p><p>Diane Wehrle
column13: insights director at Springboard
column14: said: "These results provide concrete evidence of the desire of shoppers to return to bricks and mortar stores and destinations."<p><p>The reopening of indoor hospitality on 17 May will provide a further boost to retail destinations as many indoor venues are located in High Streets and shopping centres.Catherine Shuttleworth
column15: a retail analyst at agency Savvy
column16: said good weather
column17: school holidays in some parts of the UK and a desire to go out with family and friends all boosted the figures.<p><p>A lot of people have money in their pockets and want to spend it.<p><p>I think we have overdosed on online shopping because it is boring and dull
column18: and it is also a physical sign of getting back to normal.<p><p>The opening of shops is a sign that life is returning to what it used to be.<p><p>It\'s a positive thing to put your money into the town centers.<p>

headline: <p>The prime minister must stick to indoor dining dates<p>
content: <p>A letter signed by 38 bosses urged the prime minister to stick with England\'s plan to reopen the economy.<p><p>According to data from AlixPartners Market Recovery Monitor
column5: only 23% of English venues have been able to open for outside trade.<p><p>They pointed to the Pubs Restart Scheme and said that people must not be "complacent" about coronaviruses.<p>

headline: <p>Australia has a travel bubble with New Zealand<p>
content: <p>Residents from Australia were able to travel freely to New Zealand for the first time in more than a year.<p><p>Due to tight restrictions
column5: both countries have kept infections low.<p><p>Excited passengers crowded airports in Australia for flights to various parts of New Zealand on Monday
column6: with some rising before dawn to get ready to board.<p><p>Dawn Tratt said she didn\'t know how emotional she would be at the airport.<p><p>It was a more somber occasion for many who were excited about seeing loved ones.<p><p>"My older brother passed away last week
column7: we couldn\'t get there last week
column8: but it\'s given us an opportunity to go back home today and lay him to rest
column9: said John Palalagi.<p><p>Nirali Johal said she was going to see her partner for the first time in almost two years.<p><p>She said she was looking forward to going to a caf
column10: chilling and doing what people do on a normal day face-to-face."<p><p>She said thatZoom relations aren\'t great.<p><p>Since October
column11: New Zealand travellers have been allowed to enter most Australian states without quark
column12: though this had not been reciprocated amid concerns about sporadic Covid outbreaks.Passengers must have spent at least 14 days before departure in either Australia or New Zealand to fly under the bubble\'s rules.<p><p>They must not be waiting for the results of a Covid test or have any Covid symptoms.The international departure terminal at the airport was very busy early in the day.The check-in desk had a long queue in front of it.<p><p>Some passengers told me they camped outside before the airport opened.<p><p>They couldn\'t sleep because they were so excited.The first flight was full.<p><p>It\'s a big day for airlines and a big sigh of relief for the travel and tourism industries because of Covid.This moment is about friends and family coming together.Dawn Tratt\'s voice broke as she spoke to me.<p><p>We\'re fortunate to be able to travel like that in Australia and New Zealand.<p><p>She smiled and said it was weird being on a plane again.<p><p>"Be it returning family
column13: friends or holiday-makers
column14: New Zealand says welcome and enjoy yourself."The leaders warned that the trans-Tasman travel bubble will be under constant review given the risks of scurvy-free travel.<p><p>The idea of separate travel bubbles with low-risk places like Singapore
column15: Taiwan and several Pacific island nations has previously been raised by the two countries.The nations have been praised for their handling of the disease.<p><p>Strict border controls and snap lockdowns have kept infections low.New Zealand has recorded 26 deaths.<p><p>The Australian government is facing criticism over delays in its Covid vaccine program.<p><p>The country has failed to meet its immunisation targets.Delays are likely to slow the easing of border restrictions.<p>

headline: <p>The shopping centre giant slashed rents<p>
content: <p>"Hammerson is to cut rents for its retail tenants by 30% as it aims to recover from a year of lockdowns.<p><p>The Bank of England estimates that UK households have amassed 125 billion dollars in savings.<p><p>People want to feel the products and brands in real life

column6: which ended on 31 December
column7: as more consumers chose to shop online.<p><p>We're bringing homes to the heart of the city."<p>

headline: <p>"China's economy grew 183% after the Chernobyl disaster"<p>
content: <p>China\'s economy grew a record 18.3% in the first quarter of 2021.<p><p>It\'s the biggest jump in GDP since China started keeping records.<p><p>Friday\'s figures are below expectations
column5: with a poll of economists predicting 19% growth.<p><p>They are heavily skewed and less indicative of strong growth as compared to last year\'s huge economic contraction.<p><p>China\'s National Bureau of Statistics said that the national economy made a good start and that the international landscape is complicated with high uncertainties and instabilities.<p><p>Retail sales grew 34.2% in March
column6: while industrial output rose 14.1%.<p><p>It\'s ironic that China\'s economic boom has been announced just as its leader wrestles with the problem of climate change - which has been caused by economic growth over the decades.<p><p>The Economist Intelligence Unit\'s principal economist for China predicted a number of sectors will slow as government fiscal and monetary support is reduced.<p><p>"Trade performance and domestic industrial activities for the rest of year might not be able to maintain such strong momentum due to lack of measures to stimulate domestic economy
column7:
she said.<p><p>The figures show that China has continued to grow.<p><p>The Chinese economy grew by 0.6% in the last quarter of 2020 compared to the last quarter of the previous year.<p><p>Despite a calamitous start to the year, China was the only major economy to register growth in 2020, albeit its weakest in decades, at 2.3%.China has set an economic growth target of 6% for 2021, after scrapping its target last year.<p>

headline: <p>People are waiting for new homes<p>
content: <p>The houses sold in less than three hours after dozens of people slept outside an estate agent.<p><p>The scenes - more than 18 hours before the 14 homes went on sale - were described as "bizarre."<p><p>Angharad Hamilton-Shaw

headline: <p>The US economy is growing as the recovery continues<p>
content: <p>The US economy continued to recover in the first three months of the year as businesses reopened and the government spent heavily on Covid relief for citizens.<p><p>The economy grew at an annualised rate of 6.4% in the quarter
column5: up from 4.3% in the final three months of 2020.<p><p>Richard Flynn
column6: UK managing director at financial services firm
column7: Charles Schwab
column8: said that the US economy is on solid footing despite contracting sharply in 2020.<p><p>We have experienced a deep recession and rapid recovery within just five quarters.<p><p>The strong growth was partly down to easing anxiety over the Pandemic as vaccines have been rolled out across the US
column9: boosting domestic demand and allowing businesses such as restaurants and bars to reopen.<p><p>Consumer spending hit a 14-month high in April.<p><p>The US has spent about $6 trillion on Covid relief since last May
column10: and Mr Biden pitched some $4tn of newStimulus spending in his first speech to Congress on Wednesday.<p><p>Republicans are worried about rising debt levels.<p><p>The economy could cause inflation to spike.The main policy making committee of the US Federal Reserve kept its target range for the benchmark interest rate unchanged at between zero and 0.25 on Wednesday due to the need to continue supporting growth.<p><p>The recovery is "uneven and far from complete"
column11: according to the Federal Open Market Committee
column12: which sets rates.<p><p>In a separate report on Thursday
column13: the Labor Department said initial claims for state unemployment benefits fell to a seasonally adjusted 553
column14: 000 during the week ending 24 April.Though claims have dropped from a record 6.149 million in early April 2020
column15: they remain way above normal levels.The number of people receiving unemployment benefits in the first week of April was more than 17 million.<p><p>It grew 1.6% in the first quarter
column16: which is the simple quarterly growth rather than the annualised figure published by the US Bureau of Economic Analysis.<p><p>It grew in the last three months.<p><p>The US has had a better rebound than most developed economies.<p><p>The economic effects of the health crisis are still being felt.<p><p>The data shows that there are many individual stories that show that.<p><p>The economy was behind the pre-pandemic peak at the end of the year.<p><p>The health crisis has knocked it off its growth path.<p><p>Employment rebounded from its low but has not fully recovered.<p>

headline: <p>The travel bubble is opening up in Singapore and Hong Kong<p>
content: <p>"Travel between Singapore and Hong Kong will be free from 26 May.<p><p>The travel bubble was supposed to start in November
column5: but was put on hold after a spike in Covid infections in Hong Kong.<p><p>Hong Kong got the Covid-19 situation under control.<p><p>It has been a long few months
column6: but the conditions are ripe again to re-launch the ATB.<p><p>The ATB will begin cautiously with just one flight a day.All departing passengers from Hong Kong are required to take a vaccine test within three days of departure and again on arrival.<p><p>If the seven-day moving average of unlinked community cases in either city increases to more than five
column7: the bubble will be suspended for at least two weeks.<p><p>Hong Kong's Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development Edward Yau said that the goal remains striking a right balance between public health and travel convenience so that the public will feel assured while providing certainty.<p><p>According to the Singapore Tourist Board
column8: international arrivals to Singapore declined in the third quarter of 2020.<p><p>The Pandemic has been difficult for the two cities' major airlines.<p><p>Unlike Australia's Qantas
column9: which does most of its business domestically
column10: Singapore Airlines and Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific don't have internal routes.<p><p>In the nine months to December 2020
column11: Singapore Airlines lost over a billion dollars and Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific Airways lost over a billion dollars.<p><p>If the airlines are happy to have flights again
column12: they might be able to take solace in the fact that the challenges presented by travel bubbles have yet to be solved.<p><p>The launch of the air travel bubble was delayed after a spike in cases in Hong Kong.<p><p>The process has not been easy for Australia and New Zealand.<p><p>Within a day of the travel bubble opening
column13: a cleaner at a New Zealand airport tested positive for Covid-19
column14: though officials said the case was not related to the travel bubble.<p><p>Virgin Australia decided to wait until October to join the Australia-New Zealand bubble because of border restrictions."<p>

headline: <p>There was a court battle over indoor opening<p>

headline: <p>Restaurants are having a hard time finding staff for the reopening<p>
content: <p>After thousands of workers left the sector

column8: four months our hotel is completely booked up
column9: so we\'re desperately trying to recruit enough staff."<p><p>Many UK hotels are hoping that a more UK focused holiday season will translate into a bumper summer.The trade association said chef vacancies are among the most difficult to fill.<p><p>Caterer.com said the number of vacancies on its website had grown by more than 85% in the last few weeks.<p><p>Around 3 million people were employed in bars
column10: restaurants and hotels in the pre-pandemic period.<p><p>"Many restaurants
column11: pubs and bars have experienced a sudden surge in business due to built-up customer demand and an increase in consumer confidence which is great news for the hospitality industry."Something very special would have to come along for him to return to full-time work in the industry.<p><p>"I\'ve had 15 to 20 jobs in the hospitality sector over the years
column12: from bartender to bar manager to chef
column13: so it\'s an industry I love and know inside out."<p><p>He hasn\'t turned his back on the industry completely
column14: but he\'s registered with a speciality recruitment website to look for weekend work.<p><p>He thinks it will take three to four years for the industry to get back on its feet.<p>

headline: <p>"A fifth of the sector's jobs will be lost in 2020"<p>

headline: <p>Money can be changed to learn from growth<p>

column37: automated royalty payment systems.The economic impact of this week\'s unfortunate incident in which a massive container ship ran aground in the canal is read.We came up with pie charts to show how vulnerable the canal is to the global economy.<p><p>The price could be supported by that part of the move.Over the course of the next five hours

headline: <p>There is a new patronage economy<p>
content: <p>"The non-fungible token for art and culture that have been making waves in recent weeks are economic quirks.None of the exclusive rights we usually associate with ownership are offered by them.There is an obvious question here: What are people actually buying when they buy an NFT?<p><p>Economists talk about property rights as a bundle of different rights governed by law
column5: contract and even custom.<p><p>You don't have the right to transfer something.It is possible to control something without giving others the right to not like it.<p><p>I can transfer my property to you
column6: but I want you to retain physical access or a revenue stream.The idea of divisible rights into law is built on the idea of resale royalty frameworks for art.The experience of ownership is what makes owning something enjoyable for a buyer.<p><p>The process of price discovery for the value of this pure ownership is what we are seeing in NFTs right now.<p><p>The public has a long tradition of enjoying art that is lent to a museum.<p><p>Some of the world's private collections of art are held in free port storage facilities where they are rarely seen.<p><p>An artist who receives one payment from a wealthy NFT investor is no worse off than an artist who receives a large number of payments.They are probably better off.The NFT-funded artist can continue to work in the open cultural space to gain fans
column7: sell tickets
column8: market merchandise or just get his or her art out to as wide a public as possible.A lot like the traditional patronage model of art funding
column9: NFTs allow us to financialize culture
column10: but at the same time leave it open access for anyone to view
column11: watch or listen.<p><p>While some patrons supported the construction of public monuments in their honor
column12: a lot of patron-funded art was kept in private homes and behind locked doors.Wealthy individuals can continue to support art.<p><p>Digital artists can reach a global supply of patrons instead of relying on a small community.The ownership of art can be demonstrated to anyone who wants to impress her with her taste.The art is free for the public to enjoy.<p><p>Artists and platforms need to make it easier for people to own things.<p><p>Sharing and frameworks of what constitutes legitimate sharing need to be developed.Owners need mechanisms and tools to display the art they have purchased to others that isn't just a link to an OpenSea or Rarible page.<p><p>A Creative Commons-style framework is needed to establish standard practices and expectations around use and reuse.The basis of exciting innovation in the funding and production of culture is provided by the NFT standards that have suddenly launched into mainstream consciousness."<p>

headline: <p>Can Decentralized Stable Coins Stabilize?<p>
content: <p>"Decentralized finance idealists want to create perfectly free financial ecosystems that can't be subverted by governments
column5: corporations or regulators.They want their nirvana to be equipped with stable coins so users can be protected from price craziness.<p><p>A new wave of stablecoin architects think it is possible that they are unanchored to generate traction.<p><p>They want to create money that is stable but also avoids relying on the authorities that underpin the dollar system.A stable money is important to people who participate in financial transactions.<p><p>Volatile assets do not cut it.The Centre Consortium
column6: consisting of Coinbase and Circle.J.P. Koning
column7: issued a U.S. dollar stable coin called the USD coin.<p><p>The Federal Reserve
column8: America's central bank
column9: and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation are all connected to that bank.<p><p>It may be necessary for it to carry out know your customer checks.<p><p>The most radical stablecoin experiments are empty set dollar
column10: dynamic set dollar and basis cash.This trio of stablecoins
column11: deployed on the ether
column12: try to achieve decentralization by doing away with the backing assets that traditional money issuers have always relied on to ensure the stability of the money they issue.<p><p>The supply of stable coins gets reduced as more strays are locked away.No-collateral money is a breakthrough idea for decentralization maximalists.Stable coins can be subverted by using Collateral
column13: especially when it is regulated.<p><p>Their prices were far below their target price as of yesterday. terraUSD appears to be functioning
column14: despite the fact that these experiments don't seem to be working out. terraUSD is the fifth-largest stable coin on CoinGecko and it relies on incentives.When terraUSD falls below $1
column15: traders are given an opportunity to buy terraUSD and quickly convert them into $1 worth of newly created LUNA token.<p><p>The traders make a 2-cent profit.<p><p>The effect of sucking up the excess supply of terraUSD is to bring it back to $1. frax uses the same incentive mechanism as terraUSD to maintain its $1 price.There is a layer of reserve in the frax protocol.Over the last few months
column16: frax has succeeded in maintaining a $1 price despite the fact that the remaining 14 million are unbacked.<p><p>No-collateral and collateral-lite stable coins are often advertised as technological advances.It is possible that no-collateral money isn't sustainable in the long term.<p><p>A black swan market disruption is the biggest threat to a stable asset.<p><p>People are afraid.There is a run from riskier stable assets to less-risky ones.Over-collateralization is a centuries-old plan for establishing stable money.<p><p>When a panic hits and pressure builds on the bank's $1 peg
column17: the bank can always sell this collateral and use the funds to support its peg.<p><p>They could be high risk assets that offer only the illusion of safety.<p><p>When the next big market disruption hits
column18: we will know which one it is."<p>

content: <p>It seemed tawdry and inconsequential: A tabloid celebrity cashing in on this bull market\'s version of the 2017 initial coin offering bonanza.<p><p>We risked abetting an endeavor that was silly by simply writing about it.In a field whereattention is almost as valuable as money

headline: <p>If stock-to-flow is correct
content: there should be less volatility<p>
column5: <p>The recent price rally confirms that more and more investors are interested in the virtual currency.Since the beginning of the year
column6: the price of the asset has doubled
column7: but financial analysts
column8: econometrician
column9: and value investors are still having a hard time valuing it.<p><p>It is difficult to apply quantitative valuation models when there is no interest or cash flow generated.The most controversial attempt was launched by a person going by the name of PlanB.<p><p>His model is based on the stock-to-flow ratio.The stock-to-flow ratio is an economic concept and measures the relationship between the existing supply and the annual production of any commodity.PlanB used the model to make statements about future price developments.An adapted version of the stock-to-flow model was published by the financial analyst after he was criticized.<p><p>The debate about whether the stock-to-flow model is worth applying to bitcoin is not over.<p><p>One is tempted to ask: What predictive power does the stock-to-flow ratio have?<p><p>Monetary theory
column10: where the stock-to-flow concept originated
column11: is clear on one thing: The ratio measures the hardness and thus suitability of a thing as (commodity) money.The Austrian-American libertarian monetary economist Ludwig von Mises introduced the term "commodity money" in his monumental work "The Theory of Money and Credit."One feels happy about every additional unit of money
column12: while one feels saturated with other goods at some point.The high marketability of money
column13: which is universally exchangeable against all other goods
column14: is the reason for this.<p><p>The marginal costs in production are increasing.<p><p>The more one wants to produce
column15: the more expensive it becomes.It can be assumed that all units of a good ever created are potentially still available due to a high stock-to-flow ratio.The good is unlikely to be consumed or used up
column16: but any stock is potential supply.<p><p>There is no absolute scarcity.<p><p>This is because scarcity is determined by the relationship between supply and demand
column17: i.e.
column18: stocks to flows.Supply and demand are not in equilibrium if there is scarcity.The stock of the commodity isn\'t brought onto the markets for whatever reason.<p><p>A high stock-to-flow ratio is a necessary condition for money
column19: but not enough.<p><p>A high stock-to-flow ratio is needed for hard money.<p><p>The ratio doesn\'t say anything about how market participants value the good in question.<p><p>The high stock-to-flow ratio is indicative of how hard it is to make money.The characteristics of the crypto-asset make it suitable for money.This discovery process may still be far from complete because of the characteristic facts about the coin that are currently making people discover it as money-like.<p><p>It is impossible for the stock-to-flow model to predict future price developments based on past data points.<p><p>Past results can\'t be translated into future returns with absolute certainty.<p><p>They serve to give investors hope.<p><p>In monetary theory
column20: a high stock-to-flow ratio should gradually translate into low volatility.Due to high stocks
column21: the probability is higher
column22: with other conditions remaining the same
column23: that negative supply shocks or positive demand can be offset.Potential supply in the form of stock can leave the hoards at any time and have a stabilizing effect on the price.When supply-side disruption occurs
column24: the stock-to-flow ratio of crude oil is very low.The high stock-to-flow ratio has an effect on the price of gold.<p>

headline: <p>When DeFi becomes more intelligent<p>
content: <p>\'Decentralized finance\' has captured the hearts and minds of the community in the last few months.DeFi offers a new and transparent playground to automate financial primitives such as lending or market making without the need of intermediaries.<p><p>This data can be used by machine intelligence models to better understand and benefit from the behavior of DeFi protocols.While the current generation of DeFi protocols has brought us unprecedented levels of programmability and automation
column5: the next wave will focus on intelligence as a core capability.<p><p>Artificial intelligence is eating the world and we are on the verge of an intelligent Defi era.Most of the world\'s software is being rewritten with artificial intelligence as a first class citizen.<p><p>Artificial intelligence is becoming a fundamental building block of modern software applications.The infrastructure that powers business and consumer applications is becoming smarter in nature.<p><p>The cornerstone of the first generation of successful DeFi protocols has been the automation of financial primitives such as lending or market-making.<p><p>That level of programmability and automation has started to push the boundaries of innovation creating vehicles such as flash loans
column6: automated market-makers (AMM) or on-chain insurance that are impossible to even imagine in other capital markets.There is something beautiful
column7: almost seductive
column8: about the simplicity of the x*y*k balance in UniSwap or Compound.The evolution of the market is likely to push us towards more sophisticated DeFi protocols that leverage machine intelligence as a first-class citizen.These types of protocols will enable robust levels of automation
column9: but they will be able to learn and evolve their behavior based on market activity.Imagine a group of DeFi primitives that evolve their behavior based on historical data about the market.<p><p>The current generation of lending protocols such as Maker
column10: Aave or Compound do not take into account many other factors that can enable robust borrower-lender dynamics.We could imagine DeFi lending protocols that would factor not only collateralization levels but factors such as liquidation history
column11: interactions with other lending protocols and transactional patterns to develop an intelligent and quantitative profile of borrowers and lenders.Think of this trend as an intelligent credit rating system for DeFi protocols.<p><p>In a world in which the interactions with DeFi protocols are completely transparent
column12: that data footprint can be used to create smarter insurance models.<p><p>Imagine a model in which the insurance of specific smart contracts or addresses is based on intelligent models that use quantitative DeFi factors such as the number of liquidations in lending protocols the smart contract has been exposed to or the types of pools specific addresses are supplying.Intelligence can be used in the next generation of Defi protocols to provide a very intelligent profile about specific addresses.At first
column13: the idea of intelligent DeFi protocols might seem like one of those "AI for X" ideas that attempt to insert artificial intelligence into any meaningful software trend in the market.<p><p>The core building blocks of financial services are being dis-intermediated by DeFi.<p><p>The rapid evolution of machine learning technologies is making traditional services in capital markets more intelligent.<p><p>Competing with that level of intelligence requires more than just automation and programmability.The path towards intelligent DeFi protocols is being forged by the frantic evolution of DeFi together with the mainstream adoption of machine learning technologies.The new generation of DeFi protocols won\'t automate only financial primitives
column14: but will evolve their behavior based on market conditions and utilization.<p><p>The combination of these two movements can lead to a new level of innovation in DeFi that powers a brand new generation of intelligent financial services.<p>

headline: <p>The real world can be brought on-chain by NFTs<p>
content: <p>There has been an unprecedented level of mainstream interest in the technology.Proponents of NFTs claim that they represent a paradigm shift compared to detractors who claim that NFTs are just like the initial coin offering era.<p><p>The New York Times referred to NFTs as blockchain-certified computer files.<p><p>In a previous article
column5: the Times wrote
column6: "NFTs make digital artworks
column7: and therefore sellable."<p><p>This has been followed by a sudden burst of products coming to market in a bit of a gold rush.For the purposes of this article
column8: we will stick to NFTs as digital collectibles that people love to own
column9: pay for and brag to their friends and strangers about.This is the reason why Pokemon cards and baseball cards are valuable and why NFTs such as Aavegotchis and NBA Top Shot are valuable.<p><p>Most NFTs are representations of off-chain assets.Many of the challenges associated with off-chain assets are relevant to NFTs.<p><p>An NFT can be used to bind or map a unique object
column10: such as a document
column11: image
column12: audio or video file
column13: or a physical object such as a house or a bicycle.<p><p>NFTs are not native assets.Beeple\'s painting
column14: "The First 5000 days"
column15: is a digital work of art that is not native to the blockchain.Beeple created a non-fungible token for the painting that was made of 5
column16: 000 digital works of art in desktop software.<p><p>Property rights and ownership are defined by the fact that you control the private key that can send the token to someone else
column17: and you own the token.A JPEG file and its copy both produce the same hash
column18: but with a different function.It is the Beeple token that makes the artwork worth 69 million more than a copy of the digital artwork.<p><p>I might own a Beeple artwork on ether
column19: but if Justin Sun mints the Beeple artwork on tron
column20: I will claim ownership of the artwork.A court in the U.S. might enforce MetaKovan\'s rights
column21: whereas a court in Macau might decide in favor of Sun.It depends.In the case of NBA Top Shot
column22: you own a worldwide
column23: non-exclusive
column24: non-transferable
column25: royalty-free license to use
column26: copy and display the art for personal
column27: non commercial use.When I paid for the digital collectible
column28: did my rights change as a result of that update?<p><p>If investors
column29: asset managers
column30: grandma and grandpa lose their Beeples or Top Shots to a double-spend
column31: they will vote
column32: but courts and legislators aren\'t called upon.It\'s the Beeples and Top Shot moments that have accelerated Web 3.0 like nothing before
column33: and that\'s why I\'m excited about NFTs.<p>

headline: <p>What is the meaning of NFT sales for digital real estate?<p>
content: <p>In New York City
column5: there is a row of tall
column6: skinny
column7: high-rise condominiums along the southern end of Central Park.The average apartment there sells for more than $37 million
column8: several have sold for more than $100 million
column9: and one even sold for $240 million.<p><p>Almost nobody lives in these apartments and they sit unused.Humans are notoriously bad at pricing assets
column10: especially when an asset\'s value is higher than its actual utility.Last week
column11: when Christie\'s sold Beeple\'s digital art for $69 million
column12: naturally people were aghast.<p><p>Art\'s value is based on society\'s collective agreement about its value.<p><p>The value of art has nothing to do with the cost of materials used to make it or how useful it is
column13: which is why most people cannot accurately price it.Dozens of domain names have sold for a lot of money.<p><p>The most expensive domain name sale was for carinsurance.com.<p><p>When a friend recently asked me
column14: "Why would I pay real money for fake land?"
column15: I explained that digital real estate is like a combination of N. The marginal cost to produce a digital parcel of land is almost nothing
column16: and its value is more closely related to its perceived scarcity than to its actual utility.Some might say the prices are too high.Some of the busiest streets in the world
column17: including New York\'s Madison Avenue and Broadway and London\'s Oxford Street
column18: are filled with empty storefronts.<p><p>Real-world companies have followed online shoppers.Their next stop is the metaverse
column19: where their customers are socializing and window-shopping
column20: and now even buying real-world items.Spending in virtual world environments is nothing new.People have been buying extra lives in video games for a long time.<p><p>Companies are realizing that virtual events like these can be much more cost-effective than real-world ones.Imagine the possibilities if instead of Nike having a store on every Main Street in America it built one jaw-dropping virtual retail experience in a metaverse that could sell to quite literally anyone anywhere At some point
column21: every company will realize it needs virtual stores in a metaverse like Decentraland
column22: just as they have all learned they must all have a website on the internet.<p><p>As the content inside the metaverses becomes more compelling
column23: more people will show up
column24: thus attracting more corporate sponsorships.<p><p>At $31
column25: 000 per square foot
column26: this sale broke records
column27: and people at the time felt the price made no sense.<p><p>The Beeple sale has shown us that a legitimizing force like Christie\'s can attract real-world wealth in enormous amounts.As real-world companies set up shop in virtual worlds
column28: they will drive up property values around them and foster investment in new
column29: community-building projects
column30: building a new and valuable digital real estate ecosystem with credible players and significant price tags.Some digital NBA TopShot cards that sold for $9 a pack in November have since gone for $200
column31: 000 each
column32: so we have established why digital real estate might have a value
column33: but why do It is the same reason why digital art and digital basketball cards are selling for more than their real world equivalents.<p><p>Digital real estate is now seen as valuable
column34: but its transferability will catapult its value beyond any perceived utility or scarcity value.<p><p>The prices of NFTs and digital real estate today are small compared to what they may be worth in the future
column35: once the rest of the world catches on.<p><p>The best parcels of virtual real estate will appreciate faster than real-world real estate.<p>

headline: <p>Money is being reinvented because Quantitative Easing is here to stay<p>
content: <p>Another week
column5: another NFT win.<p><p>The biggest deal of all was the sale of Beeple\'s "EVERYDAYS: THE first 5000 days" at Christies.This and other wild deals underscore a larger issue in the global economy
column6: which is how many excess dollars are sloshing around in search of finite things to buy.Global economic forces are likely to ensure that fund flow continues for some time
column7: as we discuss in this week\'s essay.In the third part of our series on the topic
column8: we talk to Roham
column9: the CEO and founder of Dapper Labs.<p><p>During last week\'s Wall Street Journal Job Summit
column10: Fed Chair Powell amplified speculation when he gave no word of deliberate actions to curb the tightening market conditions.<p><p>While Powell and the Fed wouldn\'t put their money where their mouth is
column11: the European Central Bank did.<p><p>The news that the European Central Bank would accelerate its bond-buying program sent the S&P 500 into record territory.<p><p>At the start of the COVID-19 crisis
column12: half of all cross-border loans and international debt securities were denominated in dollars.<p><p>According to the Bank of International Settlements
column13: non-U.S. banks had a record $12.4 trillion in dollar liabilities by the third quarter of last year.Dollarization increases the influence of U.S. policymaking on European financial conditions and decreases the domestic economy.<p><p>As yields rose in the U.S.
column14: eurozone borrowing costs also went up
column15: even though the European Union was worse off than the U.S. This latest move has the potential to send an opposite ripple effect across the Atlantic
column16: via the euro-dollar exchange rate.The dilemma for Powell and his colleagues is that the Fed might need to signal tighter monetary policy at some point.That would raise U.S. bond yields and widen the premium over newly lowered eurozone yields
column17: which would then drive even more European money into dollars and increase the greenback\'s value versus the euro.U.S. products would become more expensive for Europeans and European exports to the U.S. would be cheaper in dollar terms.<p><p>While you won\'t hear it from the Fed
column18: it will be concerned about the economic effects of a strong dollar.<p><p>Foreign exchange markets
column19: where the dollar weakened on Thursday
column20: seem to know that.The standard response is for the currency to fall.The euro was not the cause of the dollar heading south.The Fed now has less room to change its current
column21: easy-money course because the restored buoyancy in stock markets pushed investors into riskier bets.<p><p>Short-term rates around the world have been driven down by their bond-buying.<p><p>All risk assets have been pushed higher with unprecedented cross-market correlation as a result of filling financial institutions balance sheets with monetary reserves.Because of investors\' hyper-sensitivity to even the most subtle changes in policy
column22: central banks\' hands are tied.<p><p>Central banks put their monetary machines into top speed when there is a signal that the Fed is considering scaling back quantitative easing.The default is for more of the same because they can\'t slow them down.A relentless increase in money supply
column23: coupled with persistent increases in the prices of assets controlled by hedge funds and few other privileged investors but not by the general public
column24: is a recipe for distrust.<p><p>The charts below were used to praise the Great Moderation
column25: an almost two-decade period of resounding success for central banks.<p><p>The Fed Chair Paul Volcker imposed high interest rates in the early 1980s which allowed benchmark short-term rates to decline.<p><p>Since the crisis
column26: rates have leveled off
column27: but the falling cost of credit unlocked capital for the world.<p><p>They are at zero
column28: with nowhere else to go.In Switzerland
column29: Japan and most recently the eurozone
column30: there is a wacky situation in which lenders pay borrowers for the right to lend them money.The central banks adopted Japan\'s approach to quantitative easing as they sought to boost lending during the crisis.In order to drive down long-term bond yields
column31: central banks buy bonds and other assets from commercial banks.<p><p>When there is a signal that QE might be ending
column32: investors don\'t buy everything.<p><p>There wasn\'t any nuance.<p><p>The chart is a representation of the dilemma described in the column.<p><p>It was inevitable that the central bankers who brought us the Great Moderation would run out of money.The NFT phenomenon has hit a backlash after weeks of big-money headlines and celebrity endorsements.They are a waste of energy and a symbol of greed and wanton destruction.One of the positives of the NFT phenomenon is that it is pushing the discussion of cryptocurrencies into the mainstream.<p><p>In an opinion piece
column33: Cove Markets head of marketing Thomas Meyer said
column34: "sorry
column35: you\'re not worth $100 billion."<p><p>He warns that the trading fee revenue is overstated and that there will be stiff competition from other exchanges.Although he told CoinDesk TV that he doesn\'t plan to go public
column36: he also thinks that the company should be valued much higher than $100 billion.<p><p>The value of cryptocurrencies depends less on their utility and more on how well each one appeals to a large enough community to gain network effects.<p>

headline: <p>Bananas and Mortgages can explain the NFT craze<p>
content: <p>One way to make sense of the phenomenon is to keep in mind that a thing can be split into two things.<p><p>Before and after the split
column5: the value of each thing is in the eye of the beholder.The value of the fruit is obvious.<p><p>The peel can be used as compost in the garden.<p><p>Banana peels can be used for prank tricks
column6: such as leaving one on the floor for someone to slip on or stuffing one into a car\'s tailpipe.There was a brief fad of smoking banana peels in the 1960s.There is a point that the value of a banana
column7: and of its peel
column8: is subjective
column9: but who is to say that those kids didn\'t feel some kind of high?<p><p>If you financed a home with a mortgage
column10: chances are the institution where you send your monthly payment is not the same one that holds the mortgage.<p><p>A mortgage is an asset that can be split into parts and sold separately to different entities.<p><p>The debt is similar to the part of the banana that is eaten.It gets packaged with a whole bunch of other naked bananas into the complex securities you heard about in The Big Short.<p><p>Your lender may or may not farm out this set of administrative duties after the loan closes.A servicer manages billing and payments
column11: pays property taxes and hazard insurance on your behalf
column12: writes a nasty letter if you pay late and does other scutwork.<p><p>While you can eat the banana and keep the skin
column13: when a loan is paid off
column14: it disappears.<p><p>The investor believes that the debt has value because the holder is entitled to your monthly principal and interest payments over the life of the debt.<p><p>For the buyer of the peel
column15: servicing rights have value because the servicer earns a fee for its work.Both the mortgage and servicing rights generate income for their owners.<p><p>Depending on the outlook for interest rates
column16: home prices
column17: employment levels and probably lots of other things
column18: the answer depends on how likely you are to stay in the home.Wall Street has long employed armies of highly paid propellerheads who crunch numbers to estimate the "prepayment speed" of mortgage assets.<p><p>Nobody knows what will happen until it happens
column19: but forecasts are right or wrong in retrospect.One asset can become two
column20: and the value of each is subjective.According to anexplanation in Vogue
column21: the banana was replaced in the artist\'s instructions for recreating the work.<p><p>One reason is that you really appreciate the work and want to patronizing the artist
column22: because you believe it makes an important statement about something.<p><p>The other is for you to impress your friends at the next cocktail party.<p><p>The title of the banana masterpiece was "Comedian."Digital items can create bragging rights just like their canvas-based counterparts
column23: and are arguably more liquid as an asset class.<p><p>They can represent things like real estate and real-world assets.If you sell a tweet
column24: it will be visible to all.<p><p>If the player only signs one
column25: the card that has the most value will be the one you print.You might think $1 million for a piece of cardboard is a lot.<p><p>That is a small change.A mystery buyer paid $69.5 million for an NFT by the artist known as Beeple
column26: who was ready to pay $60 million.They didn\'t have to pay a dime if they just wanted to appreciate the work.<p><p>It doesn\'t confer the same advantage as displaying a painting in your den because it\'s a purely digital work.In the case of virtual objects that no one can solely possess
column27: NFTs have preserved or resurrected the bragging rights.<p><p>Brady Dale reported that there are now finance markets where you can pledge NFTs as security for loans.Positive side effects have been shown by the NFT phenomenon.Beeple can pursue his art without having to worry about putting food on the table.<p><p>Like financial markets
column28: the art markets are known to crash.<p><p>It is hard to imagine that a piece of art can not be hung on a wall.<p><p>You should be prepared to savor those rights for a long time.It may sound crazy to pay almost $70 million to own a picture anyone can look at for free.The time is right to sell NFTs.<p>

headline: <p>Everything is free in the future<p>
content: <p>It\'s not uncommon to hear people say
column5: "If you\'re not paying
column6: you\'re the product not the customer."<p><p>In many cases
column7: marginal costs have a bigger impact on our behavior and opportunities than up-front costs.<p><p>Computing time was expensive and you booked it in advance.Blockchains are an enormous waste of computing power by any reasonable historical standard.A lot of amazing things start to happen: mobile maps with turn-by-turn directions
column8: always- available encyclopedias and phone calls that are free

column15: the attraction of taking risk suddenly goes up as investors pursue returns.This will help speed up key technologies like optimistic rollups and near-zero capital costs.<p><p>There are some things that will not be completely free one day.<p><p>How would you describe the work of online reviewers?<p><p>The fare is nearly free because the entire trip is basically a guided tour through a series of shopping malls.I have solar panels on the roof of my house.<p><p>Think about what your business will be like if everything is free

headline: <p>"Square's Tidal Buy is explained by the NFT boom"<p>
content: <p>"The space is moving very rapidly
column5: and economic models for scarce digital media are emerging.<p><p>DJ 3LAU sold out a music album for $11.6 million
column6: while Nifty Gateway had a single piece of his art for sale.The impact on royalty models and intellectual property ownership is even more interesting.We are not saying that we should follow everyone.<p><p>Industry participants are describing the core change in market structure to others.The internet revolution is over 20 years old.Multiple waves of transformation are not just one technological change.We thought that open
column7: endless access to the world's media would be great.We would have an intellectual and scientific renaissance as a result.That has happened to some extent.<p><p>We won't belabor how little musicians earn fromSpotify
column8: but an illustration is provided.<p><p>You get $4 per 1
column9: 000 streams
column10: and need half a million to make a living in the United States.<p><p>The digital rights management efforts of the 2000s was an effort by the music labels and the publishers to take back control of p2p distribution.<p><p>It was not a grassroots effort by the artists that benefited the creators.A lot of creators love the huge audiences they are able to access and are allergic to any sort of capitalism on the internet.Being pro-file sharing is part of being techno-literate over the last 20 years.It has meant supporting the destruction of walled gardens
column11: going open source and removing legal barriers.One can own art again.Is that good?Is that bad?<p><p>A portfolio or basket of creative objects could be turned into an index that produces dividends.<p><p>You can buy downside protection and lever up that index.As an example of this already
column12: NFTX is a Defi project that has bundled CryptoPunks into indexes
column13: which can be purchased in a fractional manner.As they sell for a lot of money
column14: status symbols become hard to find.There will be an oversupply of tokenized in the medium to long term.This is still novel as creators realize they can sell directly to their audience.Supply will go through the roof once creators realize this.Demand will likely settle back down as the novelty of collection wears off.<p>

headline: <p>OG status is a liability<p>
content: <p>Australian wildlife is being made into a version ofBitcoin.We separated ourselves
column5: blocked all cross-pollination
column6: and now there\'s an isolated gene pool producing weird versions of everything.<p><p>An austere monolith?<p><p>A kingdom of solitude?I don\'t know.There is a larger point that is relevant beyond BTC
column7: and that is that a longer tenure does not equate to greater wisdom.I think September 2015
column8: when I wrote about the music-rights tracking project
column9: is the right date for the beginning of my journalism.Having watched this space for a long time
column10: I am happy to say that tenure can be a liability.<p><p>More people show up for the first time in one year than were ever present early on.It is crazy to think that perspectives gleaned in those hazy days are better than those of today.<p><p>This is not a story about lost and forgotten magicks.One of the biggest blind spots in the OG\'s is dismissing anything that is new.<p><p>There are two versions of the coin
column11: theBitcoin and theEthereum.The two are caricatures.There is still a knee-jerk attitude of not just skepticism
column12: but dismissal of any new coin or consensus mechanism.<p><p>The quality of the new architects has changed.<p><p>Tezos is a more thoughtful piece of software than Bitshares.<p><p>Is anyone interested in Auroracoin?Remember potcoin?<p><p>That is simply no longer true.<p><p>Talented
column13: well-resourced teams are behind a lot of new blockchains.Many of them will fade off into obscurity.There are lessons to be learned for the whole industry when new blockchains fail
column14: because they are afforded the benefit of the doubt and well-intentioned creators should be.Old heads who dismiss them out of hand will miss out on the lessons.<p><p>At the time
column15: it just wasn\'t kosher to talk about anything other than bitcoin
column16: but times have changed.<p><p>Not everyone has.<p><p>Prestwich wrote in his thread
column17: "It\'s past time we walked out and asked the neighbors what they\'re up to
column18: because our ivory tower is now sitting next to a small skyscraper."<p>

headline: <p>Framework Ventures raised $19 million for a capital- efficient stable coin<p>
content: <p>"The 'Fei Labs' project
column5: which is building a more capital-efficient stable coin
column6: raised $19 million from a number of people.<p><p>The U.S. dollar is one of the mainstream assets that these cryptocurrencies are designed to hold their value against.Joey Santoro said that they want to be the best stablecoin in DeFi
column7: in which they would consider DAI to be the primary competitor.<p><p>After that
column8: it would challenge other stable coins
column9: the largest of which is Tether with a $37.5 billion market cap as of Friday.TRIBE
column10: the project's governance token
column11: will be used to reward early participants in the sale and in the protocol's liquidity pools.<p><p>MakerDAO requires thousands of users to manage individual vaults of their own.BothUSDC andUSDT are centralized.<p><p>Santoro said thatFEI is basically a reserve-backed stable coin.<p><p>The white paper states that FEI can give users bonuses or charge fees for making trades that help it maintain its peg to the dollar.The developers have changed the behavior of an ERC-20 token
column12: which runs on the Ethereum network
column13: so that certain transactions can face a tax or earn a boost
column14: depending on whether FEI needs to shrink or grow supply.<p><p>Users can buy FEI from the protocol
column15: and the protocol takes those assets in reserve
column16: which we call protocol controlled value.Users don't stake the native currency
column17: but they buy it.The asset is part of the protocol after the trade.Santoro said that the assets in reserve could be over-collateralized.<p><p>You can only redeem the protocol.If and when the protocol allows other assets to be used for buying FEI
column18: the decision to add those assets will be up to holders of TRIBE
column19: the project.<p><p>Santoro said that the developers will encourage the community to only add other assets
column20: such as aDAI.Santoro said that governance will decide where to allocate the protocol's assets.The team wants to avoid repeating mistakes such as tether being opaque and MakerDAO being governance heavy and over-collateralized.You won't get much out of your sale of one unit of FEI on Uniswap because part of it will evaporate when you initiate the trade.<p><p>This is a part of the direct incentivization mechanic."<p>
