headline: <p>The second wave spreads from cities to small towns<p>
content: <p>"India's deadly Covid-19 second wave has devastated big cities.Hospitals and crematoriums have run out of space
column5: and funerals are taking place in car parks.In the northern state of Rajasthan
column6: Rajesh Soni took his father from one hospital to another in a tuk-tuk for eight hours.<p><p>At 5pm
column7: he decided to stop looking for a hospital bed because his father's condition was getting worse.<p><p>I am giving him medicine at home
column8: but I am not sure if he will survive.<p><p>We were left to die on the streets.<p><p>Several private hospitalsconned him and took money to do tests
column9: only to tell him later to take his father away as there were no beds.I spent the money on the tuk-tuk driver and hospitals.Such stories have become common in Delhi
column10: the worst affected city in India
column11: but similar accounts are now coming in from smaller cities and towns across the country.<p><p>Up to 7 April
column12: it was taking 72 days for the number of cases to double
column13: but now it is 27 days.<p><p>According to a senior journalist in the city
column14: hospitals were overrun and this suggests that the actual numbers are much higher.<p><p>Students from all over the country take exams to get into prestigious medical and engineering colleges in the district.<p><p>The district is in turmoil now that the students have left
column15: and it is largely away from the attention of national and international media.<p><p>The journalist said that the city's hospitals were not ready for a Covid wave.<p><p>He said there was an urgent need to add more oxygen and ICU beds before more people die on the streets.<p><p>In April
column16: 32% of the deaths in the city happened.There is no official data on healthcare facilities in the city
column17: but several people who spoke to the BBC said they had been unable to find a bed for their loved ones.<p><p>A senior journalist in the city said the death toll was much higher as cremation and burial grounds were open all the time.Yogi Adityanath
column18: the state's chief minister
column19: recently said there was no shortage of drugs
column20: hospital beds or oxygen
column21: but experts say the reality on the ground is vastly different.Social media is awash with posts from people from the state pleading for beds
column22: oxygen and drugs like rem An employee of one small private hospital told the BBC that arranging oxygen had become difficult
column23: but he would not complain because he feared retribution.<p><p>I don't understand why a hospital would report a shortage.He said it makes no sense. hish Yadav's father is in a critical condition in a hospital in Kanpur district but he is unable to get a bed and he doesn't have access to a doctor.<p><p>There were no Covid-19 cases in the central Indian district on 1 March.In the past seven days
column24: it has added more than 3000 cases.<p><p>There are no trained doctors to operate the life-support machines in the district hospital.The district hospital should have 49 specialist doctors
column25: but it only has seven.<p><p>There is a shortage of nurses and lab technicians.<p><p>Local journalists say that the district is not able to handle really sick patients as it did not prepare for the surge in cases.Several people have died in the district without getting proper treatment.<p><p>It has recorded a 26% increase in its caseload since 20 April
column26: and a 33% increase in deaths in the same period.<p><p>More than half of the hospital's oxygen beds were occupied.A senior official from the hospital said that out of 220 doctors
column27: 40 had tested positive in the past 10 days and four of them had died.<p><p>The pressure on the hospital has been increased by this.The west of the state is badly hit.<p><p>According to official data
column28: it has recorded more than 5
column29: 000 cases since April 5.<p><p>Senior journalists in the state say that testing is a major problem in smaller towns and cities.Many people die without ever being tested for Covid-19.<p><p>The deaths don't go into official data.The test was not done in Aurangabad.<p><p>She couldn't get a test done as her condition continued to get worse.Hospitals wouldn't admit her without a positive test result.Her family took her to a small private hospital in a nearby district where she tested positive
column30: but the hospital said she was critical and they didn't have facilities to treat her.<p><p>The tourist district in the Himalayas is struggling to cope with the rising number of cases.<p><p>More than 4
column31: 000 cases and 82 deaths have been reported in the past week
column32: and at least 131 of its 142 intensive care beds were occupied on 27 April.It is difficult for the district to handle the rise because it also receives patients from remote towns and villages.<p><p>The doctor said the situation was dire and he was terrified.The government didn't plan on augmenting facilities in remote areas.<p><p>Many people in remote Himalayan areas will die and we won't hear about it.They won't show up in statistics."<p>

headline: <p>Hospitals are overwhelmed as deaths pass 200
content: 000<p>
column5: <p>India has reached the devastating figure of 200
column6: 000 coronavirus deaths
column7: with the pressure on many hospitals showing no sign of abating.<p><p>The real number of deaths is thought to be far greater
column8: with many not being officially recorded.<p><p>Foreign aid has begun to arrive from the UK and Singapore.<p><p>Russia
column9: New Zealand and France have pledged to send emergency medical equipment
column10: and even regional rivals Pakistan and China have put aside their differences and promised to help.<p><p>A government website where Indians can register for a vaccine programme crashed soon after it launched on Wednesday
column11: as tens of thousands of people tried to access it.The numbers we are seeing are staggeringly high
column12: but the real number of deaths are thought to be much higher.<p><p>Journalists try to get a more accurate number by counting bodies at the mortuary.Sixty-eight people died on one day earlier this month in the state
column13: according to health officials.<p><p>The number of Covid funerals in the capital
column14: Lucknow
column15: alone
column16: was pointed out by a Hindi newspaper.<p><p>Some say they were asked to help speed up the process by piling the wood themselves.<p><p>It is one of the worst-hit cities in India
column17: with some estimates saying there are about 300 active Covid cases per square kilometre.<p><p>It was well organised for the first surge.The World Health Organization reported in its weekly epidemiological update that there were nearly 5.7 million new cases reported globally last week - and India accounts for 38% of them.<p><p>India is heading towards state elections and there is increasing anger towards both state authorities and the central government for the handling of the Pandemic.<p><p>Prime Minister Narendra Modi has been accused of ignoring scientific warnings to participate in election rallies and allowing a massive Hindu festival to go ahead in northern India.<p>

headline: <p>Turkey enters first full lockdown<p>
content: <p>"Some people went to the main bus terminal to get out of Istanbul while others tried to stock up on alcohol after news of a booze ban.<p><p>This was the mood in the hours before Turkey went into its first full pandemic
column5: to curb a surge in infections and deaths.<p><p>One year on
column6: it is among the countries worst affected by Covid
column7: with the highest infection rate in Europe.<p><p>Ankara is still proud of its relatively low total number of deaths
column8: at around 39
column9: 000.<p><p>After a second period of restrictions began in November
column10: the number of daily cases fell to around 6
column11: 000.<p><p>But as soon as the government started to ease the restrictions in March
column12: a new wave struck Turkey.<p><p>At its peak in April
column13: there were more than 300 deaths and more than 60
column14: 000 new infections.Some argue that the lockdown won't be effective if it isn't supported by a faster vaccine programme and that it won't last long enough to combat the rise in cases.<p><p>Turkish society is determined to see the back of this most recent wave
column15: and the government has a clear target.<p><p>The tourist industry hopes that the lockdown in Turkey will allow a reopening in time for the summer season.<p><p>Please email haveyoursay@hello.co.uk if you would like to speak to a journalist.If you can't see the form on the page
column16: you can email HaveYourSay@hello.co.uk or use the mobile version of the website to submit your question or comment.<p><p>Please include your name
column17: age and location in your submission."<p>

headline: <p>One dose of vaccine halves transmission<p>
content: <p>A single dose of a coronaviruses vaccine can reduce household transmission of the virus by up to half
column5: according to a study.<p><p>Not only do vaccines reduce the severity of illness and prevent hundreds of deaths every day
column6: we now see they also have an additional impact on reducing the chance of passing Covid-19 on to others.<p><p>Similar results could be expected in other settings with similar transmission risks
column7: such as shared accommodation and prisons.<p><p>Public Health England said it would expect the same results in other high-risk settings.<p><p>The vaccination campaign is making good progress into younger age groups
column8: which is good news for the continued easing of restrictions.<p><p>A cause for concern
column9: though
column10: is whether newer versions of the virus
column11: which might be more resistant to vaccines
column12: might cause a new surge in infections.<p><p>The expert opinion is that the current vaccines will provide a significant degree of protection
column13: especially against severe illness.Most of the people in the study were under the age of 60.<p>

headline: <p>"The guidance from the US Covid-19 is that fully-vaccinated people don't need masks outside"<p>
content: <p>According to new guidelines from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column5: people who have received all required jabs can ditch their face coverings if alone or in small groups.<p><p>The bottom line is that if you\'re vaccinations
column6: you can do more.<p><p>The president called it a "patriotic" act for Americans who haven\'t received their shot yet.<p><p>"Vaccines are about saving your life but also the lives of the people around you - but they\'re also about helping us get back closer to more normal living."<p><p>Health officials presented the new safety guidelines on Tuesday.<p><p>This includes exercising or dining outdoors.She said that determining whether to wear a mask in larger outdoor gatherings would depend on other concerns like how well-ventilated a venue is and how much space is left between people.<p><p>Early studies show that people who are fully vaccined are less likely to spread the disease.<p><p>More than 120 million Americans have received at least one vaccine dose as of April 26
column7: according to the CDC.<p>

headline: <p>Sore arm and headaches are the most common side effects of covid vaccine<p>
content: <p>"According to a UK study
column5: the most common side effects of the Covid-19 vaccines are pain or tenderness at the injection site.<p><p>The ZOE Covid Symptom Study app saw fewer reactions than were seen in clinical trials.<p><p>Since the end of last year
column6: more than 80% of people think the vaccines are safe and effective
column7: compared with 70% who think the same by the end of 2020
column8: according to a survey of 5
column9: 000 people.<p><p>About 70% of people having the Pfizer jab had some reaction to where the needle went in
column10: compared with just under 60% for the AstraZeneca jab.<p><p>The trend was reversed for those reactions that affect the whole body rather than just the site of the injection.<p><p>After the first and second dose
column11: this was only 18% for the Pfizer vaccine.<p><p>The most common side effects were headaches.<p><p>The after effects of the vaccine are usually mild and short-lived
column12: according to the study's lead scientist.<p><p>The study didn't look at what happened after a second dose of the Oxford-AstraZeneca jab since hardly anyone had received it at the time of the study.<p><p>One in four people who used the ZOE symptom app had at least one of the whole body reactions and two-thirds had a local reaction.Half as many people had a whole body reaction as were recorded in clinical trials
column13: which may be because people in the trials were younger and healthier.<p><p>The lead author of the paper said the results supported the safety of both vaccines and should help allay safety concerns of people willing to get vaccine."<p>

headline: <p>The opposition in India wants a full national lockdown<p>
content: <p>There has been a "virtual collapse of health services" and a lockdown is needed to "break the chain" according to a spokesman for the Congress.<p><p>The government said cases are slowing down
column5: but testing numbers have also dipped meaning the true caseload could be far higher.<p><p>The Indian Express reported that members of India\'s Covid-19 taskforce
column6: which advises the central government
column7: are pushing hard.<p><p>The decision to impose restrictions in India is made by individual state authorities rather than the central government.<p><p>Many states have still introduced restrictions despite Prime Minister Narendra Modi saying that they should only consider restrictions as a last option.<p><p>The capital
column8: Delhi
column9: and the financial hub
column10: Mumbai
column11: are all under restrictions after the northern state of Bihar announced a full lock down.<p><p>Prime Minister Modi was heavily criticized last year for imposing a nationwide lockdown with less than four hours\' notice.<p><p>It caused a humanitarian crisis as tens of thousands of migrant workers were left without work and forced to walk hundreds of kilometres to their home villages.<p><p>It has overwhelmed its hospitals and delays in testing
column12: diagnosis and treatment - as well as a shortage of critical care beds and crucial drugs - have resulted in a spike in deaths.<p><p>There have been long lines at crematoriums
column13: mass funeral pyres and cities running out of space to bury or cremate the dead.<p><p>India\'s cases have risen over the past week
column14: but at a slower rate than in the past.There are daily cases falling in Delhi
column15: UP and Maharashtra.<p><p>There was "cautious hope" that there would be some respite from the second wave.Lav Agarwal
column16: joint secretary of the health ministry
column17: said progress needed to be sustained by "containment measures at district and state level".<p><p>India has administered more than 157 million vaccine doses which ranks third in the world after China and the United States.India is the world\'s biggest producer of vaccines and only 2% of people have received both doses.<p><p>The vaccine rates are down.<p><p>The chief executive of India\'s Serum Institute
column18: the world\'s biggest vaccine manufacturer
column19: has warned that there will be shortages for months.<p>

headline: <p>Plans for overseas tourists to return were unveiled by the EU<p>
content: <p>Anyone who has received the last dose of an EU-approved vaccine at least two weeks prior will be allowed to travel.<p><p>The EU has already announced plans for a digital certificate
column5: which would cover anyone who is eithervaccinated against Covid-19
column6: has a negative test or has recently recovered.Member states will be able to accept tourists.<p><p>The decision will include the ability to verify the authenticity
column7: validity and integrity of the certificate and whether it contains all relevant data.<p><p>The measures will not affect current rules on essential travel or EU citizens and long-term residents and their families.<p><p>The EU has approved four vaccines so far.The same jabs have been approved for emergency use by the WHO
column8: with similar approvals for China\'s Sinopharm and Sinovac expected in the coming days and weeks.<p><p>It is working with the WHO to ensure the certificate is recognised beyond Europe.<p><p>The 27 member states also want to include non-EU countries such as Norway
column9: Iceland and Switzerland
column10: with officials saying earlier this week that vaccine travellers from the US may also be able to visit Europe this summer.<p><p>The UK government is working on a digital system for international travel that will show travellers their vaccination status.<p><p>Practical concerns over the EU certificate include questions over how long immunity lasts after an infection and whether further jabs will be needed.<p><p>The "Green pass" has created travel opportunities for Israeli citizens
column11: following deals with Greece and Cyprus.<p>

headline: <p>The UK is sending more ventilators to India<p>
content: <p>"As India continues to report soaring infections and record deaths
column5: the UK's chief medical and scientific officers have also spoken with their counterparts there to offer advice."<p>

headline: <p>There was backlash after China Weibo posted a joke about the India Covid crisis<p>
content: <p>"A social media post from an account linked to the Chinese Communist Party has sparked controversy for appearing to mock India over its coronaviruses crisis.Hu Xijin

headline: <p>I did the best I could for her<p>
content: <p>It comes with risks
column5: but I will do the best I can for her.In my mind
column6: I just had to do it
column7: and that\'s what I did.<p><p>But on her seventh attempt she became pregnant and things seemed to progress well until her 20-week Scan showed she had spina bifida.She will need a shunt to drain the fluid from her brain later on
column8: and they said it was likely she would be paralyzed.<p><p>I couldn\'t stop crying when I was told all the possible outcomes for this condition.<p><p>"They told me the probability of her walking or moving her legs was very
column9: very low - and that was absolutely devastating."Within days
column10: she was referred for tests and told she was eligible for surgery.<p><p>A team of around 25 clinicians carried out the complex operation to repair her baby\'s exposed spinal cord and close the hole in her back.<p><p>There is some fluid on her brain
column11: but so far she is showing signs of good development.<p><p>Thirty-two babies have undergone the procedure since January 2020.<p>

headline: <p>The French lockdown has been lessened to help schools and travel<p>
content: <p>French children have returned to classes in schools across the country and a domestic travel ban has been lifted as the government eases its third Covid lockdown."<p><p>The third lockdown
column5: lighter than the previous two
column6: took effect in March and a night-time curfew remains in effect.<p><p>Along with eating places
column7: France is keeping non-essential businesses
column8: shopping centres and leisure facilities shut.While the youngest children have been able to attend school classes
column9: secondary pupils have been kept at home
column10: relying on remote learning.<p><p>Most secondary pupils were able to return to school on Monday.<p><p>The lyce students are subject to social distance
column11: meaning classes are only half-full.<p><p>The numbers were restricted in the 15 French districts with the highest infections in the 13 to 15 age group.<p><p>Paris and areas around the capital are some of the worst hit by Covid.<p><p>Elsewhere in Europe.<p>

headline: <p>The new president challenges the denial<p>
content: <p>President Samia Suluhu Hassan is more conciliatory than her predecessor
column5: who was autocratic.<p><p>I have been following the debate
column6: and I must say it is not healthy for our nation
column7: she told MPs a month after she was sworn in.<p><p>The very first time she stood on stage as president, her aura, choice of words and demeanor promised a completely different type of leadership.<p><p>She is making bold announcements, which is something that has not been experienced since the arrival of the bulldozer, said Deodatus Balile, managing editor of Jamhuri Media.<p><p>She has a different approach to Covid-19.<p><p>The global warnings over coronaviruses were downplayed by Magufuli, who refused to allow Covid-19 vaccines into the country.<p><p>There are no reliable statistics on infections or deaths from the virus in the country as the government stopped releasing them in May last year.Within three weeks of taking office, she formed a committee of experts to advise her on how to keep people safe.<p><p>She wore a face mask on her visit to Uganda, but it was not in her home country of Tanzania.<p><p>It\'s true that no new policies have emerged from the expert committee, with new versions of the disease being reported across the globe.People are waiting to find out if she would consider curfews and lock downs as a way to contain the virus, which her predecessor rejected.<p><p>Such measures would affect millions of poorer Tanzanians, including informal traders who are the support base of the ruling party - Chama Cha Mapind President Samia would need to bring out her qualities of persuasion if she were to go down that path.The president ordered the information ministry to reverse previous decisions saying the government should not give people a chance to say that we are limiting press freedom.<p><p>It is expected that President Samia will take a less aggressive stance towards international companies in the country.<p><p>A subsidiary of a Canadian company was hit with a massive tax bill over royalties the government said it owed.<p><p>The bill was reduced as part of a settlement with the government, which included sharing future economic benefits more equitably.<p><p>President Samia is due on Tuesday to make her second international trip, this time to Kenya, in her seven weeks in power.I am certain that the new president will be more outward facing and will put the country back on the global map
column8:
he says.<p><p>President Samia\'s approach to leading the country is not about tarnishing her predecessor\'s reputation but rather aboutchoosing.<p>
0,2,<p>Blood clot have been reported with all Covid-19 vaccinesThe author says they're wrong"<p>
column9: <p>The study didn\'t show that
column10: according to the lead author.<p><p>The study of Moderna and Pfizer\'s vaccines did not find anyone with blood clot.There were no scary things happening with Johnson & Johnson.<p><p>Among the more than 7 million people who have received the Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine
column11: at least seven have experienced very rare blood clot in the brain -- one man during clinical trials and six women during the vaccine\'s roll out.<p><p>Johnson & Johnson is coming under fire for stoking fear about Pfizer and Moderna\'s vaccines when in fact Johnson & Johnson\'s shot is the only one authorized in the US with reports of blood clot.<p><p>A small number of people who received the Pfizer or Moderna vaccine developed low platelet levels as a result of the study by Lee and her colleagues.<p><p>"That is a really irresponsible thing to say
column12: said Dr. Paul Offit, referring to the J&J media statement.Offit, a vaccine expert at the University of Pennsylvania, is a member of the FDA advisory panel that reviewed emergency use authorization applications from all three Covid-19 vaccine manufacturers.<p><p>A member of the vaccine advisory panel to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Dr. William Schaffner said that he thinks Paul is right.His indignation is appropriate.<p><p>In an email to CNN, a J&J spokesman did not directly respond to questions about why the company had said there had been reports of blood clot.<p><p>CNN pointed out some issues in the J&J media statement.The company did not repeat the claim that there had been reports of blood clot with all vaccines.<p><p>The issue of blood clot and the Johnson & Johnson vaccine first arose on April 9 when the European Medicines Agency issued a statement that it was investigating reports of blood clot among people who had received the Johnson & Johnson vaccine.<p><p>J&J issued a media statement saying that they are aware that there have been reports of thromboembolic events with all COVID-19 vaccines.<p><p>Thromboembolic events" is a medical term for blood clot.Lee and her colleagues looked at some adverse events reported after people received the Covid-19 vaccines manufactured by Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna.<p><p>The study looked at reports of people with low blood platelet levels
column13: not blood clot reports.<p><p>"They are completely different entities
column14:
said Lee, the study\'s lead author.<p><p>It\'s like apples and oranges.<p><p>The Pfizer or Moderna vaccine caused 17 people to experience low blood platelet levels for the first time.<p><p>The reports were not surprising, given that tens of millions of people had received the vaccine.<p><p>More than 30 million people in the US have received at least the first dose of either Pfizer or Moderna\'s vaccine, according to the CDC.<p><p>There are many causes for low platelet counts, including pregnant women, heavy alcohol consumption, and viral infections.It has been linked to very small numbers of rare blood clot.<p><p>There is a link to a study in the Johnson & Johnson April 9 media statement.There was no increased incidence of certain types of blood clotting disorders among people who had received Pfizer or Moderna.According to the Wall Street Journal, Johnson & Johnson sought help from Pfizer and Moderna to look into reports of blood clot, but both companies declined, saying their vaccines appeared to be safe.<p><p>The company issued a statement to CNN saying that they believe collaborative scientific exchange can lead to more robust answers to questions, particularly as it relates to the safety of patients.<p>
0,2,<p>The US surgeon general wants everyone in the country to get the vaccine<p>,<p>The vaccine is the most important way to end the epidemic.The US Surgeon General said Monday that everyone in the country needs to bevaccinated.<p><p>The first thing we have to do is get the vaccine.Turn around and ask our family and friends if they\'re going to get vaccinations.If they need help, we have to help them.<p><p>More than 200 million doses have been administered in the US, with an average of 3 million shots per day, according to the CDC.<p><p>Hesitancy slows down the vaccine leg.<p><p>The highly contagious B.1.1.7 variant, first spotted in the UK, has been reported in all 50 US states, according to the CDC.<p><p>If young adults don\'t do their part, the Pandemic could drag on indefinitely, health experts say.A big part of the country\'s 65+ population, which got priority access to vaccine before younger Americans, has already been vaccinations.<p><p>The shift in Covid-19 cases is down to a younger and younger age group.<p><p>We have to start getting serious about this
column15: she said.<p><p>Most of the increase in Covid-19 cases and emergency room visits in the US are for younger adults, according to the CDC Director.<p><p>Hospitals in Michigan are filling up with younger patients in the middle of a violent surge.It really is presenting in all of our ERs and frankly in our inpatient units

column17: among more than 7.9 million Americans who took the single-dose vaccine.<p><p>Emergent BioSolutions was asked by the FDA to stop manufacturing the J&J vaccine at a plant.The vaccine advisers to the CDC will meet Friday to discuss whether the J&J vaccine may have caused blood clot

column19: what to do about it.<p><p>Anthony Fauci
column20: director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
column21: said he expects a decision soon.<p><p>I hope we don\'t see anything after Friday.<p><p>"We need to get Friday some decision

column23: so experts can gather all the necessary data to help inform their decision."<p><p>The Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna vaccines were the same as the J&J vaccine.<p><p>More than 76 million Americans have been fully vaccined with the Pfizer/BioNTech or Moderna vaccines

headline: <p>There is a possible link between blood clot and Covid-19 vaccines<p>
content: <p>Even though the link is not yet firm
column5: they\'re calling the condition vaccine-induced immune thrombotic thrombocytopenia or VITT.It is characterized by a low number of blood-clotting cells called platelets.The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration are checking to see if the vaccine is linked to dangerous clot and hemorrhaging.<p><p>The FDA and CDC have asked for a pause in giving out the J&J vaccine while they investigate.The findings support a theory that an immune reaction might underlie the rare blood clot
column6: but the findings don\'t yet explain it.A reaction by the immune system with platelets is what may be going on.<p><p>It might not be happening more often in recently vaccined people than in the general population.The symptoms developed more than five days after the first vaccine dose.<p><p>Although there have been a few reports of patients with symptoms consistent with this clinical syndrome after the receipt of other vaccines

column6: based on increasing complaints from them.<p><p>In response to the survey results
column7: the Ohio Board of Pharmacy voted unanimously Tuesday to create a committee to make recommendations on addressing issues raised by the survey.<p><p>The Board looks forward to working with stakeholders on its newly formed Pharmacist Workload Advisory Committee to discuss this important issue and develop recommendations to promote safer working conditions for pharmacists and pharmacy staff.Most of the pharmacists in those work environments said they didn\'t feel they had enough staffing for patient safety and that they felt pressured to meet metrics that could interfere with patient care.<p><p>When asked for additional comments at the end of the survey

column11: and extensive care is taken to foster it

Greg Abbott lifted the state\'s mask mandate and withdrew most of his Covid.The decision has led to tensions with some local governments, including a high-profile clash after the state\'s attorney general sued Austin officials for refusing to enforce the governor\'s order to end the mask mandate.<p><p>She was eligible due to a chronic condition and was able to schedule an appointment in early March, though it was an hour away from her home.She hopes to be able to drive people to their vaccine appointments if transportation is a barrier for them.<p><p>He wants other people to have the same sense of security.<p><p>I feel good and I can share that with the people I\'m helping.I hope they feel that relief once they get that vaccine, too, she said.<p><p>They\'re taking the next step to protect themselves.<p>

headline: <p>Sleeping too little in middle age may increase the risk of dementia<p>
content: <p>"Researchers have pondered the link between sleep and cognitive decline for years.<p><p>It is difficult to know if insufficient sleep is a symptom of the brain changes that underlie dementia
column5: or if it can actually help cause those changes.It followed almost 8
column6: 000 people in Britain for 25 years.<p><p>It found that people who slept six hours or less on an average weeknight were 30 percent more likely to be diagnosed with dementia than people who slept seven hours or more.<p><p>The question of which comes first

column9: a neurologist and co-director of the Center on Biological Rhythms and Sleep at Washington University in St. Louis.There is a chance that they are capturing people in middle age before they have Alzheimer's disease pathology or plaques and tangles in their brain.The team was able to adjust for several behaviors and characteristics that might influence people's sleep patterns or dementia risk
column10: said an author of the study.<p><p>Depression and mental health disorders are linked with sleep problems.The correlation between short-sleepers and increased risk of dementia was found in the analysis of participants without mental illnesses.<p><p>Even if it is modestly associated with dementia risk
column11: short sleep can be important at a societal level.As with other research in this area
column12: the study had limitations that prevent it from proving that inadequate sleep can cause dementia.<p><p>Most of the sleep data was self-reported
column13: a subjective measure that isn't always accurate
column14: experts said.The quantitative measure came late in the study

column16: making it less useful than if it had been obtained at younger ages.<p><p>Some cases might have been missed because of the use of electronic medical records.Robert Howard

column20: the longer their neurons are active and the more amyloid is produced.<p><p>Some scientists think it's important to get enough sleep in certain phases.<p><p>Too little sleep can cause conditions that are known to be dementia risk factors.She said that people with low motivation for physical activity are those who stay up too late and have snacks.There is a shared genetic link between shorter sleep and increased risk of Alzheimer's.<p><p>Some studies have shown that people who sleep too long are more likely to have dementia.<p><p>There was an association between long sleep and increased risk
column21: but it was not statistically significant.There appeared to be increased dementia risk in people who shifted from short to normal sleep.<p><p>She said getting a good night's sleep should make naps unnecessary because it will make up for missed sleep.She said that people with sleep disorders should consult sleep specialists.According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column22: having a regular sleep schedule

column24: and removing phones and computers from the bedroom are some of the sleep hygiene guidelines.<p><p>We still don't know how the relationship actually occurs in people and what to do about it."<p>

from post traumatic stress disorder.<p><p>He said that if he got separated from his team and was lost in a town, the bullets would dribble out of his gun.<p><p>Ostrom dropped out of college because of headline: <p>The Psychiatry Confronts its Racist Past<p>

column6: which featured Rush\'s image on its logo until 2015

headline: <p>The robot surgeon is going to see you<p>
content: <p>Sitting on a stool several feet from a long-armed robot
column5: Dr. Danyal Fer wrapped his fingers around two metal handles near his chest.As he moved the handles up and down
column6: left and right
column7: the robot mimicked each small motion with its own two arms.<p><p>One of the robot\'s tiny claws did the same when he pinched his thumb and forefinger together.This is how surgeons operate on patients.After this brief demonstration
column8: Dr. Fer and his fellow researchers at the University of California
column9: Berkeley showed how they hope to advance the state of the art.A new kind of computer software took over after Dr. Fer let go of the handles.<p><p>Many of the same technologies that underpin self-driving cars
column10: drones
column11: and warehouse robots are being used to automate surgical robots.The father of robotic surgery said that it is an exciting time for these methods
column12: which are still a long way from everyday use.<p><p>The aim is not to remove surgeons from the operating room but to ease their load and perhaps even raise success rates.The hope is that automated robots can bring greater accuracy to other tasks
column13: like incisions or suturing
column14: and reduce the risks that come with overworked surgeons.<p><p>He said that his wife still had her hands on the wheel
column15: even though the car was driving on its own.She would take over when it was time to leave the highway.Five years ago
column16: researchers with the Children\'s National Health System in Washington
column17: D.C. designed a robot that could automate the surgery of a pig.<p><p>The method is far from practical
column18: as the markers are not easily implanted or removed.<p><p>Artificial intelligence researchers have improved the power of computer vision
column19: which could allow robots to perform surgical tasks on their own
column20: without markers.<p><p>A neural network can learn to recognize a cat by analyzing thousands of cat photos.Neural networks can learn from images captured by surgical robots.<p><p>The video streams into a viewfinder that surgeons peer into while guiding the operation
column21: watching from the robot\'s point of view.But afterwards
column22: these images also provide a detailed road map showing how surgeries are performed.They can teach new surgeons how to use the robots and train them to do their own work.<p><p>Dr. Fer and his colleagues took pictures of the robot moving the plastic rings.<p><p>Their system learns from the images that the best way to grab the rings is by passing them between the claws and moving them to new pegs.The robot missed the spot by millimeters when the system told it where to go.Over months and years of use
column23: the many metal cables inside the robot\'s twin arms have stretched and bent in small ways
column24: so its movements were not as precise as they needed to be.<p><p>The problem with automated technology is that it struggles to deal with change.<p><p>The Berkeley team decided to build a new neural network that analyzed the robot\'s mistakes and learned how much precision it was losing with each passing day.Brijen Thananjeyan
column25: a PhD student on the team
column26: said that it learns how the robot\'s joints evolve over time.The robot could grab and move the plastic rings if the automated system could account for the change.<p><p>It is like a car where the lane-following is autonomously but you still control it.<p><p>Plastic pegs moving is one thing
column27: but cutting
column28: moving and suturing flesh is another.An associate professor at the University of Texas
column29: Austin asked
column30: "What happens when the camera angle changes?"For the foreseeable future
column31: automation will be something that works alongside surgeons rather than replacing them.<p><p>The signal lag is too great to allow doctors to perform surgery across distances greater than the width of the operating room.<p><p>Dr. Fer said that if a robot could handle some of the tasks on its own
column32: long-distance surgery could become viable.<p><p>Surgeons will need new tools when people are on the moon.<p>

content: <p>The Supreme Court denied an appeal from Pennsylvania Republicans who said the secretary of state had no authority to extend the deadline for receiving mail-in ballots in the 2020 general election.<p><p>Pennsylvania officials urged the court not to take up the case because the election was over and the total number of ballots was not at issue.The Republicans challenged the secretary of state\'s decision to allow three extra days for receiving mail ballots
column5: saying only the legislature could authorize such a change.<p><p>Republicans brought similar challenges to voting changes in other states
column6: all based on the claim that only legislatures can make substantive changes in voting procedures.<p><p>In the 2000 Bush v. Gore case
column7: four justices and some lower court judges said that because the Constitution provides that every state must choose its presidential electors
column8: only the legislature can change voting rules.<p><p>The Supreme Court said the Constitution\'s reference to "legislature" in a separate but similar clause meant the entire lawmaking apparatus
column9: not just the two state houses.<p>

headline: <p>On the way home<p>
content: <p>Did you leave your hometown?Springfield
column5: Missouri
column6: is a strange place to visit because it sparks so many memories for meI moved to New York City two years agoI miss my hometown a lot as I build my new life hereThings I Miss:1 is on my current list<p><p>There is a talent show<p><p>The cheese is Provel<p><p>My first grade teacher lives next to my parents<p><p>A teacher who watched me dance to "Like a Virgin" for show-and-tell<p><p>Downtime<p><p>Target is a fully-stocked Target<p><p>My aunt made a casserole with potatoes and corn<p><p>There are 14 attics<p><p>Stock tanks are used as swimming pools<p><p>My dad uses an empty water bottle as his ping-pong paddle and makes it a fair game<p><p>The neighbors are chatty<p><p>The sunsets are pretty<p><p>The sport is called Midwest skiing<p><p>The water tastes a bit sweet<p><p>I swore all of the backyard locations were Leprechaun doors<p><p>I heard piano lessons<p><p>The sidewalks are covered in chalk<p><p>Teenagers are in truck beds<p><p>Andrew25<p><p>Knowing everyone\'s name<p><p>There are brown recluse spiders<p><p>There is a fear of an old porch swing collapsingThe sunglasses are on top of the baseball capsThere are long lines at the storeI sneaked out of my parents house in high schoolLeeches7The basement was floodedThere were tornadoes9The family didn\'t fill me in on gossipI know I made the right decision when I moved away from SpringfieldI fear that the town will change and I will no longer be a part of itI remind myself that I am also changing<p>

content: <p>"Are you traveling for the holidays?We are staying home for Thanksgiving and then heading to California for ChristmasAfter four California trips
column5: we figured out how to beat jet lag after the three-hour time changeHere are our steps<p><p>You can book an evening flight<p><p>You should go for pizza<p><p>Allow them to watch TV<p><p>The hotel pool has a swimming pool<p><p>If they need a nap
column6: give them an afternoon nap<p><p>Encourage them to stay up as late as possible because they will be exhausted by the time they crash<p><p>They will be able to sleep if they can get to their regular time<p><p>Since 7pm New York time is only 4pm California time
column7: kids will want to go to bed later<p><p>If they skip their naps that day
column8: they will be sleepier by the time they get to bed<p><p>They will probably go to bed a bit later the first night

headline: <p>It was the first bug in more than 30 years<p>
content: <p>The cow wheat shieldbug was found in Scotland for the first time in more than 30 years.<p><p>There are two white spots on the insect\'s black body.<p><p>Scientists said there had been "worrying declines" of the insect in the south-eastern part of England in recent years.<p><p>The cow wheat shieldbug is found in sheltered grassy or wooded areas with a warm micro-climate.<p><p>The bug has suffered from a decline in traditional woodland management.<p><p>Diverse woodlands are becoming a key feature of the Cairngorms National Park.<p>

column6: she has hit out at world leaders for not doing enough.<p><p>You have to allow yourself to enjoy the ride.You shouldn't be doing this if you can't have fun or if you get depressed because of it.<p><p>She says the wind-powered voyage across the Atlantic Ocean was tough but a staple of British food kept her going.<p><p>I only ate cans of baked beans.<p><p>She admits her love of British food stops there

headline: <p>Climate change will affect coffee in a warming world<p>
content: <p>Scientists say a "forgotten" coffee plant that can grow in warmer conditions could help future-proof the drink against climate change.<p><p>As temperatures rise
column5: good coffee will become increasingly difficult to grow
column6: and they predict we could soon be sipping a rare wild coffee from West Africa that tastes like Arabica coffee
column7: but grows in warmer conditions.<p><p>The coffee tasted amazing and we were completely blown away.<p><p>It has these other attributes related to its climate tolerance: it will grow and crop under much warmer conditions than Arabica coffee.<p><p>"It\'s not going to be in coffee shops in the next couple of years
column8: but I think within five to seven years we\'ll see it entering the market as a niche coffee
column9: as a high value coffee
column10: and then after that I think it will be more common."<p><p>Arabica beans have a better taste.<p><p>The coffee is grown in the mountains and accounts for over 60% of the world\'s coffee production.Arabica has limited resilience to climate change; farmers are already experiencing the impacts of elevated temperatures and low or erratic rainfall.Other threats to coffee production include price fluctuations
column11: pests and diseases

column13: but only a few are used for drinking.<p>

headline: <p>The hut gave rise to the sea level benchmark<p>
content: <p>"An anonymous red-and-white concrete hut that has that familiar battered seaside look is celebrating an important anniversary.<p><p>Newlyn's efforts to begin measuring mean sea level during WWI were not the first attempt to track the highs and lows of tidal movements around the UK.<p><p>The Cornish station was in an excellent position to do so as scientists came to understand the complexity of capturing and fixing a robust reference.<p><p>The pier stood on stable granite and the harbour was close to the open ocean
column5: which made it less affected by the waters that swirled around other stations.<p><p>A float connected to a chart-recording gauge monitored the ups and downs of Newlyn's tides
column6: and temperature
column7: barometric pressure
column8: and salinity were also taken.<p><p>At the end of the six-year investigation
column9: ODN was determined to be 15.588ft (4.751m) below this mark
column10: which made it possible to describe elevations anywhere in the country using Newlyn as a reference point.<p><p>When calculating height above a mathematical surface known as the ellipsoid
column11: gravity sensor data can be used to calculate an elevation above mean sea-level to a few millimetres. height-zero should be somewhere around where you get your feet wet if you are standing on a beach.Understanding how air pollution will move around tall structures in a city
column12: knowing where to site solar panels or cell towers
column13: and planning the routes of new rail are all dependent on accurate mapping.<p><p>The legacy was founded in that hut on Newlyn's South Pier on 30 April 1921."<p>

headline: <p>"World's glaciers are melting at a faster pace"<p>
content: <p>According to a new study
column5: the world\'s glaciers are melting at an accelerated rate.<p><p>A French-led team assessed the behavior of nearly all documented ice streams on the planet.<p><p>The scientists tell the journal that the meltwater produced now accounts for about a fifth of global sea-level rise.<p><p>Over the last 20 years
column6: glaciers have lost more than 260 gigatonnes per year.<p><p>He says on this week\'s edition of Science In Action that it\'s enough to cover all of Ireland in 3 million gallons of water each year.<p><p>The worldwide inventory of glaciers contains 217
column7: 175 ice streams.A mid-sized country like the UK can be compared to some of the smaller pitches.<p><p>The research team
column8: led by Romain Hugonnet from the University of Toulouse
column9: France
column10: used as its basis the fact that they are thinning and retreating in a changing climate
column11: either through stronger melting in warmer air or because the patterns of snowfall that feed the glaciers have shifted.That\'s in large part because every single glacier examined in the study is represented based on the same methodology.<p><p>It had an average loss of 281Gt/yr over the period 2000 to 2019.<p><p>The changes taking place are disrupting water supplies for billions of people downstream and causing glaciers to melt a quarter of Earth\'s ice loss over the satellite era."Although the rate of glacier melting has increased steadily
column12: the pace has been dwarfed by the ice losses from Antarctica and Greenland
column13: and they remain our primary concern for future sea-level rise."<p>

headline: <p>Michael Collins was one of the Apollo 11 astronauts<p>
content: <p>Michael Collins
column5: one of the three crew members of the first manned mission to land on the Moon
column6: Apollo 11 in 1969 has died at the age of 90.<p><p>He spent his final days peacefully
column7: with his family by his side
column8: they said.We will miss you.<p><p>Mike always faced the challenges of life with grace and humility
column9: and faced this
column10: his final challenge
column11: the same way
column12: the Collins family said in a statement.<p><p>We will honor his wish for us to celebrate, not mourn, that life, because we know how lucky Mike was to have lived it.<p><p>Collins spoke at launchpad 39A, where the crew\'s rocket began the historic mission, and described how he felt during take-off.Your whole body is shaking.This gives you a different idea of what power really means.<p><p>We crew felt the weight of the world on our shoulders, we knew that everyone would be looking at us, friend or foe.Michael Collins was crucial to the success of the mission.<p><p>Collins piloted the command module while Neil and Buzz flew across the lunar surface.<p><p>He performed important maneuvers in space to get to the Moon.<p><p>He was positive that he didn\'t have the best seat of the three.<p><p>After leaving Nasa
column13: he had a brief spell in politics
column14: but later retired to Florida
column15: where he painted and wrote.At the age of 88
column16: he admitted that he never really enjoyed the spotlight of public life.His name will live on
column17: as a new generation of astronauts prepares to return to the Moon in the next few years
column18: following the trail blazed by Collins and the other pioneers of Apollo.<p><p>"That\'s one small step for man
column19: one giant leap for mankind" was whatArmstrong said when he beamed his words to the world.<p><p>The US was able to demonstrate its power to a world audience.<p>

headline: <p>The Brazilian tribe warns that they are killing the forest<p>
content: <p>The livelihoods of some of the world\'s most vulnerable indigenous communities have been devastated by the rise in Brazilian Amazon deforestation.Our chief environment correspondent
column5: Justin Rowlatt
column6: has been trying to find out what this has meant for an Amazon tribe he first met in 2010.<p><p>I had expected a yawning cultural chasm would make it difficult to connect with the people
column7: but I felt like Mr Bean when I first visited them a decade ago.<p><p>Some of the older tribespeople had grown up in the Amazon rainforest without ever having contact with the outside world.<p><p>The Awa found my incomprehension about the ways of the jungle hilarious.When I tripped over the roots of the jungle path and was offered a charred and rotten monkey to eat
column8: my hosts laughed at me.<p><p>Despite the plight of the community
column9: they remain good natured despite my visit being a source of great entertainment.<p><p>When I visited in 2010 my best friend in the community
column10: Pirai
column11: told me they could hear chainsaws in the rainforest.The last people on Earth who still try to live as traditional hunter-gatherers live in a 289
column12: 000-acre forest reserve.<p><p>For decades
column13: loggers and farmers have been invading their ancestral lands and clearing the forests
column14: and two years ago the threat to the Awa got even greater.The world would need to give Brazil $1 billion in foreign aid a year in order to stop the illegal destruction of the Amazon.<p><p>I had been invited to witness the culmination of a Brazilian government effort to stop the destruction of the Amazon.I will never forget watching Pirai and his friend Hamo step nervously into a helicopter for the first time.<p><p>The effort saw the Brazilian army
column15: air force and military police working alongside the country\'s environmental protection service in a mission co-ordinated by the Funai agency.<p><p>Their camp was like a military base in Afghanistan.<p><p>It was crawling with heavily armed soldiers and equipment.The farmers were served with notice to leave and were offered land elsewhere in the state if they did so.<p><p>I remember one farming family loading everything they owned onto a truck and I watched as it rumbled away to their new life
column16: leaving a The government gave the force a small fleet of helicopters and new vehicles and ordered it to be protected by the police and army.<p><p>The equipment of anyone found razing the forest was given permission to be destroyed by the environmental police.<p><p>A blacklist of farmers and loggers involved in illegal activities was set up which made it harder for them to sell their produce.<p><p>By 2012 it had fallen to the lowest level since records began.<p><p>"That rare thing
column17: an environmental battle that is actually being won"
column18: I wrote at the time.<p><p>The Brazilian government\'s own satellite monitoring agency reported an increase in the number of fires in the Amazon in 2019."If things are quiet
column19: let\'s do this all at once and change all the rules
column20: he said.<p><p>He said he meant to say simplify" the rules.<p><p>A senior officer in Brazil\'s environmental police force says that environmental protection has been rolled back in the Amazon.<p><p>He told me that the job has become a guerrilla warfare.<p><p>Environmental police officers are being attacked by mobs and loggers trying to keep them out of the forest.<p><p>"In places where we didn\'t have incidents in the past
column21: now loggers
column22: prospectors
column23: squatters are rioting"
column24: the officer said
column25: shaking his head in exasperation.<p><p>The Brazilian government doesn\'t think it\'s doing anything to undermine environmental protection.<p><p>Local officials have sometimes withdrawn police protection for environmental officers
column26: but it is not official policy
column27: and the rules on burning equipment have not changed.I wanted to know how the Awa were doing.<p><p>It seemed like a long time before we got a reply.<p><p>There was a recorded message from Pirai.<p><p>I could hear birds in the background
column28: but his words were frightening.<p><p>He told me that the chainsaw is still buzzing.<p><p>He sent some photos of the community.<p><p>I knew many of the faces.<p><p>They didn\'t look like the people I had spent time with a decade earlier.<p><p>"Loggers
column29: farmers
column30: hunters
column31: invaders...they are all coming back
column32: Pirai said.They are killing our forest."<p>

headline: <p>The first module of a new space station was launched by China<p>
content: <p>"China has launched a key module of a new permanent space station
column5: the latest in Beijing's increasingly ambitious space programme.<p><p>The Long March-5B rocket was used to launch the Tianhe module
column6: which contains living quarters for crew members.<p><p>China hopes to have a new station up and running by 2022.<p><p>The International Space Station is the only space station currently in use.<p><p>China is a late starter when it comes to space exploration.In 2003 it became the third country after the Soviet Union and the US to send a human into space.<p><p>Simple modules allowed only short stays by astronauts at the trial stations.The new station is expected to be operational for at least 10 years.<p><p>The core component is tianhe.<p><p>It is long and wide.It will provide power and propulsion and contains the life support technologies and living quarters required by visiting astronauts.Beijing plans to have at least 10 more similar launches
column7: carrying all the additional equipment into orbit
column8: before the completion of the station next year.It will travel at an altitude of up to 450 km.<p><p>China wasn't allowed to participate in it.<p><p>There is a chance that the only space station in Earth's orbit will be left by the retirement of the International Space Station.China's space programme has become a regular feature in the country's propaganda videos and
column9: in a way
column10: why wouldn't it?<p><p>After a high-speed catch up with other nations
column11: it now has bold ambitions beyond Earth.<p><p>China became the first country to send an uncrewed rover to the far side of the moon in 2019."<p>

headline: <p>A small green rock is warning about climate change<p>
content: <p>The rock is greenish in colour and just over 4 cm in length.The piece of sandstone was recovered from the deep ocean far off the coast of modern-day West Antarctica.<p><p>The scientists who found it say it shouldn\'t have been there.<p><p>It was taken off the White Continent by a glacier

headline: <p>When silence descended over Victoria Falls<p>
content: <p>In our monthly feature

column8: locals refer to Africa\'s greatest waterfall as "the smoke that thunders".The chasm was carved by the action of water along a natural fracture zone in the volcanic rock that makes up the landscape in this region of southern Africa.<p><p>As news of the low waters spread
column9: local traders noticed a drop in tourist numbers.As well as hitting the countries\' economies

column11: which are dependent on hydroelectric generation.<p><p>The region is recording a sequence of extreme droughts that reflect what climate modellers have predicted will occur as a result of an increase in greenhouse gases in the world\'s atmosphere.<p><p>This makes the storage of the water in the region more difficult
column12: and makes the impact of the extended dry season more damaging to people and the environment.<p><p>The warming trend is expected to continue.The worrying fact facing politicians
column13: policymakers and civil society is that the continent is set to be hardest hit by climate change
column14: yet the capacity to adapt to the realities of a warming world are low.<p><p>Africa is on the front line of the battle against dangerous climate change.<p><p>Our Planet Then and Now will continue each month up to the UN climate summit in Glasgow

headline: <p>Climate justice calls are shaking the world<p>

column5:
said the 19-year-old climate activist when world leaders took to the (virtual) stage at President Biden\'s climate summit.<p><p>There are warnings of carbon inequality in wealthy countries.Amy Norman, a researcher at the think-tank, The Social Market Foundation, says politicians need to level with voters on what the transition to net zero will mean for the way we live.<p><p>If politicians hit lower incomes where it hurts with their finances, they\'re going to lose support quickly and especially if that\'s seen to be unfair.<p><p>Where would you charge for a tower block?<p><p>Some of the issues politicians must wrestle with as they work out how to deliver on their promises for curb emissions are: Poor people are losing two to three times more than rich people when hit by a flood or storm in Bangladesh, India, and Honduras.<p><p>Dr Bjoern Soergel of Germany\'s Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research says the drive towards net zero could mean higher prices for food and energy.<p><p>This would involve carbon pricing - essentially a carbon tax on polluting fossil fuels - with governments re-distributing some of the profits on a per capita basis.Richer countries would then need to give a fraction of the money to the countries where people live in extreme poverty.<p><p>Most of the issue has been contributed to by them.<p><p>They have the biggest means to tackle the problem both in terms of financial resources and technology.<p>

headline: <p>The ants have a chance to become Queen<p>
content: <p>"The Indian jumping ant
column5: Harpegnathos saltator
column6: has many talents.This inch-long arthropod
column7: found in flood plains across India
column8: has a four-inch vertical leap and can take down prey nearly twice its size.Scientists found that Indian jumping ants can shrink their brains by 20 percent and unshrink them in a matter of weeks.<p><p>The researchers behind the study say that females of the ant species use this ability to prepare their bodies for reproduction.<p><p>The queen is the most powerful person in the colony. queens live more than five times longer than worker ants because they are waited on hand and foot.<p><p>In a typical colony
column9: the queen is the only female that can have offspring.When a queen Indian jumping ant dies
column10: about 70% of the females in her colony enter a battle Royale-style tournament that lasts up to 40 days.The victors get to spend the rest of their days pumping out babies
column11: as soon as the tournament begins.Although worker ants and gamergates are similar in size
column12: their internal anatomy is vastly different
column13: according to a new study.<p><p>The researchers believe that these ants shrink their brains to conserve energy
column14: a behavior also observed in Etruscan shrews
column15: a tiny mammal that sheds brain size in winter to keep other parts of its body warm.<p><p>A professor of biology at Boston University who was not involved with the study said the brain is a costly organ to operate.When female Indian jumping ants transform into gamergates
column16: most of the energy that was once spent on the brain gets diverted to parts of the body that are responsible for reproduction.<p><p>The researchers think that the ability to switch between worker and gamergate evolved as a means of ensuring that those that fail in their bids to be queen can.<p><p>They can be a model for understanding things like epigenetics and the control of plasticity in organisms
column17: even scaling up to humans."<p>

headline: <p>There is a new suspect in the fairy circles mystery<p>
content: <p>In the Australian outback
column5: certain grasses grow in eerie rings
column6: with ramparts of dusty green standing at the edge of wide circles of bare red dirt.These rings of spinifex grass look like structures first spotted in the Namibian desert and are often described as "fairy circles."A small study published last month in the Australian Journal of Botany suggests that microbes living in the soil may contribute to the rings\' formation.<p><p>Researchers have looked at whether the soil is too dry for growth
column7: whether it is too dry for insects
column8: and whether the spinifex is being destroyed by insects.There is no consensus on what is driving the formation of rings.A small European swamp grass grew in a ring pattern because of a build up of soil pathogens in the middle.She and Neil Ross wondered if sterilizing the soil from inside rings would make it easier for plants to grow in it.<p><p>The researchers found that the seeds were easier to grow in containers of interior soil that had been sterilized.The number of seeds that were sown in the soil from outside the rings that had not been sterilized was the same as the number of seeds that were sown in the inner soil.It seems that sterilizing the inner soil removed whatever was keeping plants from growing.<p><p>If new spinifex grasses can\'t handle the pathogens in the soil at the center of their clump
column9: they may sprout instead just outside of it
column10: leading to that signature ring pattern.<p><p>Dr. Moles thinks that some other soil microbes can help.<p><p>Killing potential pathogens from inside the ring makes that soil livable again
column11: she says
column12: but killing everything in the soil outside might have detrimental effects as well.Microbes may have joined the party in the ongoing scientific discussion of the fairy rings.<p>

headline: <p>The job of science adviser has been elevated by BidenIs that what science needs?<p>

column6: the enzyme finds it and slices it.The phone camera can detect a signal that the virus is present when the extra molecule is sliced by the enzyme."Smartphone cameras are 10 times more sensitive than lab-based devices in detecting the signal fast and reliably within minutes

headline: <p>"Chris Silverwood takes charge after Ed Smith's role was abolished"<p>
content: <p>"Ed Smith's role as England national selector has been abolished in a restructure of the way the England men's teams are selected.<p><p>Smith said he was excited about watching England's continued development and wished the coaches and support staff good fortune.<p><p>I know how hard he and his team work.<p><p>I would like to wish Chris Silverwood good luck."<p>

headline: <p>What happens after legal challenges and broken trust in the European Super League?<p>
content: <p>The 12 clubs who want the European Super League are pressing ahead with their plans.<p><p>Those who don\'t are getting ready for the fight.The passion is running high.The vast majority of the opinions are against the project.The ferocity of it has not caught them off guard because they knew what would happen.<p><p>There are five clubs involved in the semi-finals next week.<p><p>Lawyers are talking to Uefa about these matches.<p><p>It is difficult to see the clubs being kicked out at this stage but Ceferin did not deny it could happen when pressed on the subject.<p><p>A statement released by the world governing body late on Sunday
column5: which said Fifa "disapproved" of the Super League plans
column6: was felt to be a weak response by those who believe they have been betrayed by the bigger clubs.The task of stopping the Super League will become very difficult unless Infantino adopts a stance in line with Ceferin.<p><p>They reached this conclusion from different points of view.<p><p>The clubs say there is no reason why the Champions League can\'t be a part of their own competition.Uefa chiefs don\'t see the situation the same way.<p><p>The European club competition is the number one competition.<p><p>This goes to the heart of the issue.<p><p>After almost two years of negotiation
column7: Uefa
column8: with support from the European Club Association
column9: has finally announced a new version of the Champions League.<p><p>The first phase will be a league format
column10: instead of groups of four teams playing each other twice.<p><p>The clubs will play 10 matches against each other.<p><p>In theory
column11: this increases the number of attractive games.<p><p>The teams with the highest Uefa co-efficient who qualified for European competition will get two of the additional four places.<p><p>If the concept was in place this season
column12: it would be the most likely beneficiaries.The clubs don\'t think the plans go far enough.<p><p>They want high-profile games when they play.<p><p>The statement released on Sunday by the 12 clubs included contact numbers for public relations agencies in Germany and France
column13: which gives credence to the view that
column14: if they get that

column16: but there is no plan for how the additional five teams from the 15 founder members will be selected.According to Super League sources
column17: this could be accomplished through a qualification system in the European competition.<p><p>If we are talking about the best supported teams

column20: Porto
column21: Roma
column22: Ajax and Shakhtar Donetsk would be the entrants.<p><p>This is all speculation for now.Nobody knows

column24: so 2022-23 is a more realistic option
column25: although even that will be optimistic unless there is some change of position.<p><p>Is there any trust in the beginning?<p><p>When six clubs were accused of backroom dealing
column26: clubs were arguing about Project Big Picture.<p><p>At one point the second wave of the Pandemic threatened to close the league down again
column27: yet they have continued to meet as a premier league.The break up of the premier league in 1992 was divisive.<p><p>The clubs want to continue playing in it.<p><p>There will be no battle for the top four because virtually all the clubs are fighting to finish.<p><p>It would be almost impossible for those six clubs not to finish in the top six because of the financial gap between the Super League clubs and those excluded.If broadcasters pay more for European rights
column28: it could affect the amount of money they pay the league.<p>

headline: <p>"Fight Talk: 'Dead in the water' to 'this fight is on'"<p>
content: <p>One promoter says it\'s dead in the water
column5: the other says the fight is on.In this week\'s Fight Talk
column6: we discuss the latest ups and downs in the Anthony Joshua negotiations.<p><p>The Chisora fight week included an awkward breakfast
column7: a phone call from mum Chisora and a split decision which could have gone either way.<p><p>We discuss how the boxing world reacted to Britain\'s newest world champion becoming a world champion
column8: and how the boxing world reacted to the spectacularKatie Taylor vNatasha Jonas clash which lived up to all the hype.<p><p>The fight will last a maximum of 36 minutes.<p><p>The wait for the biggest all-British fight in boxing history feels like it has been going on for 36 years.<p><p>The back and forth between Anthony Joshua\'s and Tyson Fury\'s representatives continues.<p><p>Nine months after we were first told that a two-fight deal had been agreed

column15: promoter politics

column24: with the main event being a fight between Britain\'s Derek Chisora and New Zealand\'s JosephParker.<p><p>The build-up to fight week was full of weird and wonderful.<p><p>Just a couple of days before the two men traded leather
column25: Chisora and Parker nattered away over breakfast as if they were best buddies...And then there was the whole ring walk controversy on Friday as Chisora lost a coin toss to decide who walks first or second.<p><p>If he had to make his entrance first
column26: the Londoner would pull out of the fight.<p><p>Chisora was prepared to leave the bio-secure bubble hotel.<p><p>The fight went ahead after Chisora\'s mother convinced him to change his mind
column27: according to his manager David Haye.<p><p>The man who has beaten Chisora twice thought he won by two rounds.<p><p>The boxing correspondent for Radio 5 Live said he made the winner of the fight by three rounds.<p><p>In his post-fight interview
column28: he said he wasn\'t sure if he\'d be given the decision.<p><p>What should Chisora do now?<p><p>Some fans think he should retire because he has lost 11 of his 43 fights.<p><p>He called for an immediate rematch after quashing any idea of retiring.<p><p>You think the 37 year old may still have something left in the tank.<p><p>In last week\'s Fight Talk
column29: we suggested that two people could steal the show in Manchester.<p><p>And so they did.<p><p>With all of the world lightweight belts on the line
column30: Irishwoman Taylor\'s hand was raised yet again with a close points win over her opponent.<p><p>The fight was of the highest standard and should have been the main event.<p><p>Current fighters

headline: <p>The climbers are aiming to boost diversity<p>
content: <p>He was raised in the outskirts of Los Angeles but moved to Montana when he was in college.<p><p>He fell in love with the outdoors and the ice climbing opportunities in Montana.<p><p>Ainuu taught himself how to climb and is now a seasoned professional

column25: that would be white folk stuff
column26: Martin says.Martin has fostered a strong relationship since the trip to Montana.<p><p>One of the driving forces behind the film\'s conception was Anker, who has long pushed for better diversity in outdoor activities.Martin and Ainuu say it\'s important to have White allies in the sport.Martin says that there is one thing for you to do.<p><p>The death of George Floyd in 2020 was a wake up call for the global climbing community, according to Anker, who acknowledges that not enough has been done in the past to make climbing inclusive.<p><p>Anker tells CNN Sport that it\'s trying to change the view of climbing.<p><p>It has always been the domain of the white male to see this as an athletic pursuit.<p><p>As big expeditions go forward, there is more inclusivity from both genders.<p><p>Anker hopes Black Ice" will encourage people from all walks of life to adopt his love for climbing

headline: <p>The author says we should be less afraid<p>
content: <p>It wasn\'t easy.The US climber had powered on through the dark and dealt with a deep cut to her head to become the first woman to free climb the Golden Gate route in under 24 hours.<p><p>She became the fourth woman to free climb the monolith within a day

column11: hit her head on a ledge

column15: an experienced climber and mountaineer.<p><p>Honnold helped for the first two thirds of the climb.<p><p>The rope was attached to the top of the wall and Honnold was at the bottom.<p><p>The technique is risky because it helps speed up the ascent.Ballinger took over belaying duties near the top where Harrington knew she would have to slow down.<p><p>The couple took it pitch by pitch
column16: with Harrington waiting for her partner to catch up before taking on another section.<p><p>He was the one who supported me while I practiced on the wall

column18: her hands slipped off the ground

column20: out of body
column21: flow state experiences
column22: where you don\'t really even think and you\'re just sort of like that
column23: she said.<p><p>Millions of Americans waited to see who their new president would be, but the climb distracted them from what was arguably one of the most important days in US history.<p><p>She admits that attempting the feat on election night was semi deliberate and that she had always planned to be ready in early November.<p><p>She said that everyone in this country was feeling a lot of uncertainty and lack of control.<p><p>It worked out, I definitely thought about it a lot less than most people.As an only child, her competitive edge began with a healthy rivalry with her cousins.<p><p>She remembers the first time she competed against them on a small, local climbing wall.<p><p>After signing with the North Face, she became the US sport climbing champion five times and twice winning the North American championship.<p><p>She moved to California and began climbing in the park.<p><p>She said she felt fear quite frequently.I work through it by accepting it and trying to understand why it\'s there and then taking steps to move forward."<p><p>It\'s a valid emotion and we shouldn\'t shy away from it.<p><p>We can use it as fuel and strength.<p><p>There are a number of challenges in Europe that she\'s keen to take on

headline: <p>"'When we come together it's powerful

headline: <p>"He was convicted for a crime he didn't commit and now he's selling art to the Obamas"<p>

headline: <p>US owners have a checkered history of investing in English soccer<p>

column6: according to the club\'s CEO.<p><p>I\'m not sure what the people in that club know about the club.<p><p>Sunday\'s postponement of the game between Manchester United andLiverpool due to fan protests -- that at times turned ugly -- brought into sharp focus the discontent of many supporters over the way the Glazer family have run the premier league\'s most successful team.<p><p>Police estimate over 1
column7: 000 protesters invaded the pitch at United\'s Old Manchester stadium.<p><p>A group of 200 people gathered outside The Lowry Hotel

column12: a competition consisting of 12 of the biggest teams in European football.<p><p>Although the venture fell apart less than 48 hours after it was first announced
column13: the lack of fan consultation galvanized many supporters -- not just at United -- who are intent on wresting back some semblance of control they pay good money to watch.Fans are charged up to $132 to attend a game.<p><p>The strength of feeling and the right of fans to know what is happening were acknowledged by the Premier League in a statement on Monday.<p><p>"We are committed to maintaining close dialogue with supporters and their representatives
column14: as we work with The FA and Government to identify solutions
column15: but ask that all protests are peaceful
column16: the statement said.<p><p>CNN reached out to the Glazer family, as well as Henry and Kroenke.<p><p>The Manchester United Supporters Trust (MUST), a group of more than 200,000 club supporters, said in a statement on Monday that not one member of the Glazer family has ever had so much as a conversation with them.<p><p>The fans who spoke to CNN were worried that the club would be saddled with debt and that the family would only care about its brand and revenues.<p><p>Before the Glazers bought the team, Manchester United was debt-free.<p><p>The net debt of the club is over half a billion dollars according to the club\'s latest accounts.<p><p>The club had a net debt of $283.16 million in December of 2019.<p><p>The net investment of $240.3 million in player acquisitions over the past two years is more than any other major European club.<p><p>Over a billion dollars has been spent since the beginning of the year.<p><p>In 2010, MUST organized a protest in which fans wore green and gold scarves to games, the club\'s original colors.<p><p>MUST demanded a response from the Glazers by Friday, after it outlined a four-point plan to rebalance the current ownership structure in the favour of supporters" in a Monday statement.The plan called for fans to have the same voting rights as the Glazer family.<p><p>One of the points is that fans of Manchester United can buy shares in the club until they are reduced to a minority or being bought out altogether.That type of model is a nod to the 50+1 ownership rule prevalent in German football
column17: where external investors and commercial partners are not allowed to gain control
column18: instead ensuring members
column19: often also fans

column27: you were clear that it wouldn\'t work.<p><p>We heard you.<p><p>I heard you.<p><p>Henry apologized to the players and to the people who work so hard to make the fans proud.<p><p>They have no responsibility for this disruption.<p><p>They were the most disrupted.<p><p>This hurts the most.<p><p>They work hard to make you proud.<p><p>I know that the entire team has the expertise
column28: leadership and passion necessary to rebuild trust and help us move forward.<p><p>Current owners have run into trouble by looking at club ownership like owning any other business

headline: <p>Everton condemns the big six for the Super League split<p>
