headline: <p>Damage was found after the brain of a player was donated for research<p>
content: <p>"The first contact sportswoman in Australia to have her brain donated to the Australian Sports Brain Bank has died.<p><p>White matter changes and repeated head injury have been linked to the development of mental illness and an increased risk of suicidal thoughts.<p><p>The brain bank has received donations from male contact sport athletes before.Both were found to have severe cases of chronic traumatic encephalopathy
column5: a neurodegenerative disease attributed to their playing careers.<p><p>Over the course of four seasons
column6: she played 23 games for the Greater Western Sydney club.The findings on her brain have opened up new areas of inquiry in sports concussion
column7: according to the brain bank.She previously represented Australia in baseball
column8: playing at five World Cups
column9: and was also an American football quarterback in the short-lived LFL Australia
column10: and later in the United States.<p><p>While a long-term career in contact sport is becoming widely accepted as a substantial risk factor for the development of CTE
column11: less well understood is how white matter changes in the brain from non-concussive or sub-con.<p><p>White matter injury was found around the altered vessels.<p><p>I hadn't noticed that before in other subjects
column12: but we haven't had many athlete donors as young as Jacinda before.<p><p>Changes to the white matter of the brain have been observed in contact sports players after a single season.<p><p>The two areas of research have not coalesced.The white matter damage from concussions and head injuries can affect mental illness.There is white matter damage and blood vessel damage as well.<p><p>She donated to the brain bank because she wanted to help people and be a shining light for other women in the games.<p><p>It is important that we balance the ledger here and not just talk about men all the time
column13: because research is biased towards men in this area.<p><p>We need to make sure that scientific research doesn't just reinforce harmful social stereotypes.<p><p>In the US
column14: very few women have come through the studies.In Australia
column15: the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14.Samaritans can be reached in the UK and Ireland by email or phone.<p><p>There are other international helplines at www.befrienders.org."<p>

headline: <p>"Baseball's rules were made to be broken"<p>
content: <p>"On Saturday the Los Angeles Dodgers hosted the San Diego Padres in what has become baseball's hottest rivalry.After taking a chest-high cutter from the Dodgers'Trevor Bauer on the game's first pitch for a strike
column5: Fernando Tatis Jr struck back on the very next throw
column6: essentially hitting the exact same pitch.<p><p>It was your classic cut-to-the-chase moment
column7: one of baseball's biggest bats getting over on its reigning Cy Young winner.What came next was even more shocking.As Tatis was rounding first base
column8: he slowed down
column9: looked back and cupped a hand over his right eye.Baseball is a sanctified thing that should only be played in a certain way
column10: and this was the real shot for baseball fans.Deadpan.<p><p>It is hard to hit in the big leagues.In a 13-minute video
column11: Bauer broke down the celebrations.After the first home-run pitch
column12: Bauer gives Tatis high marks for calling back to the one-eyed stare that Bauer flashed at the Padres hitters he retired during spring training.After the second home-run pitch
column13: which missed the outside of the plate by a foot
column14: Bauer continues to Bauer said that he had an issue with this location and that he had to go for it.There needs to be more of a shoulder swing.The arms are not open.The head needs to move a bit.<p><p>Curry does a shoulder shimmy.<p><p>Jordan shrugged.<p><p>His chest was beating and he was stepping.These aren't the only moments that make Jamie Foxx look like himself.Fans tuning in for the next game are the moments that get them.The soccer pitch has a lot of time for goal scorers to indulge themselves.<p><p>They are taunting one another and watching a show.<p><p>Even though most of them know that the melodrama is scripted
column15: there is something about the passion and the emotion that spills over the top that speaks to them.<p><p>The thing that always rings true is if America's pastime were truly this hallowed training ground for instilling fairness and merit in leaders of tomorrow.<p><p>The racial
column16: political and economic problems that still divide us are explained by baseball.<p><p>A game where the only object is to hit a small
column17: fast- moving ball with a long slender stick is called a game.<p><p>Let that man remind us not to take the spectacle for granted if no one throws up gang signs or drags a finger across the throat.The kids could do with more stand-out moments like the one at Dodger Stadium last Saturday.On the other side
column18: there was avenging and building on the Dodgers rivalry.Bauer was taking his time while giving a lesson in how to resolve and escalate a conflict at the same time.<p><p>The best of them can be brought out of a little conflict.<p><p>So be it
column19: if that should happen with the flip of a bat.Bring it on
column20: baby."<p>

headline: <p>"Big Tech's stock price surge is a huge shot in the arm for pensions"<p>

headline: <p>Parts of Yahoo and AOL are being explored for sale<p>
content: <p>"The telecommunications giant looks to exit an expensive and unsuccessful bet on digital media as it explores a sale of assets including Yahoo and AOL.<p><p>AOL and Yahoo were acquired byVerizon for more than $9 billion in total
column5: and other details couldn't be learned.<p><p>Yahoo and AOL

column9: and in February of this year

headline: <p>The government and industry are pushing for regulation of the digital currency<p>
content: <p>Government and industry officials are zeroing in on regulation of cryptocurrencies as the key to combat an epidemic of ransomware
column5: which is when hackers freeze the computers of a target and demand a payoff.<p><p>While those have won greater acceptance among investors over the past year
column6: they remain the lifeblood of ransomware operators and other criminals who face little risk of prosecution in much of the world.<p><p>Companies
column7: government agencies
column8: hospitals and school systems are among the victims of ransomware groups
column9: some of which U.S. officials say have friendly relations with nation-states.He wouldn\'t comment on the report before it was released.<p><p>Central bank regulators and financial crime investigators around the world are debating if and how cryptocurrencies should be regulated.The task force included representatives from the FBI and the United States Secret Service as well as major tech.<p><p>It will recommend steps such as extending "know-your-customer" regulations to currency exchanges
column10: imposing tougher licensing requirements for those processing cryptocurrencies
column11: and extending money-laundering rules to facilities such as kiosks for converting currency.<p><p>"This is a world that was created to be anonymous
column12: but at some point
column13: you have to give up something to make sure everyone\'s safe."Last week
column14: authorities arrested a man in Los Angeles and accused him of laundering more than $300 million through a service that combines transactions from multiple cryptocurrencies to obscure who is paying whom.<p><p>The Marshals Service signed a $4.5 million deal with BitGo
column15: a California-based exchange
column16: to hold and sell more forfeitedcryptocurrencies.<p>

headline: <p>There has been a tipping point for reining in tech<p>
content: <p>"The European Commission plans to unveil far-reaching regulations to limit technologies powered by artificial intelligence.<p><p>Their motivation is different.<p><p>In the United States and Europe
column5: there is concern that tech companies are stifling competition
column6: spreading misinformation and eroding privacy; in Russia and elsewhere
column7: it is to silence protest movements and tighten political control; and in China
column8: it is some of both.<p><p>Britain is creating a tech regulator.New powers were given to India over social media.Russia stopped the flow of traffic.<p><p>It began compelling internet firms to publicly promise to follow its rules against monopolies.Daniel Crane is a law professor at the University of Michigan and an antitrust expert.Mr. Crane said that the regulatory response to the 2008 financial crisis was the same as the American trustbusting of steel
column9: oil and railroad companies in the 19th century.The 10 largest tech firms have a combined market cap of more than $10 trillion.While governments agree that tech clout has grown too expansive
column10: there has been little coordination on solutions.<p><p>Facebook hoped that the techno-democracies in the U.S.
column11: Europe
column12: India and elsewhere would work together to preserve and enhance the democratic values at the heart of the open internet and prevent it from fragmenting further.<p><p>He said that balkanized
column13: inconsistent regulations could make things worse.<p><p>The presumption that success can only be the result of anticompetitive behavior is simply wrong
column14: according to Amazon.On Dec. 9
column15: the Federal Trade Commission and nearly every state filed bipartisan lawsuits accusing Facebook of acting anticompetitively.European policymakers introduced a competition law and new requirements for blocking online hate speech less than a week later.<p><p>The companies that dominate online advertising
column16: search
column17: e- commerce and app marketplaces have faced questions about whether they have used their clout to buy competitors
column18: promote their own products ahead of others and block rivals.<p><p>New antitrust
column19: privacy and speech regulations are being drafted by Republican and Democratic lawmakers.<p><p>They want to trim a law that shields sites like YouTube from being sued.The chairman of the House antitrust subcommittee
column20: David Cicilline
column21: said in a statement that it was not just for the United States but for the entire world.In order to take on the monopoly power held by the largest tech platforms and restore competition and innovation to the digital economy
column22: Mr. Biden has picked tech critics for key administration roles.<p><p>The threshold for intervention against platforms would be lowered under a proposed antitrust law.<p><p>The risks of artificial intelligence will be addressed in the draft regulations that will be released on Wednesday.<p><p>They have bowed to government demands in a number of countries.Over the last year
column23: the country has fought with both Facebook and Google over a proposed law that would require them to pay news publishers for content shared on their platforms.Google threatened to make its search engine unavailable in Australia to protest the legislation.<p><p>He said it was in line with how the web has operated over the past three decades.<p><p>The biggest turn against the tech companies has been in China.For years
column24: Beijing blocked foreign websites and policed content on domestic platforms
column25: but last year allowed Chinese tech firms to buy rivals
column26: develop new products and expand.<p><p>Beijing telegraphed its desire to bring to heel an industry characterized by cutthroat competition and huge influence over sensitive political issues like labor and data security in regulatory and legal proposals.The initial public offering of Ant was halted days before it was scheduled.The one-two punch was a blow to Jack Ma
column27: an entrepreneurial icon
column28: who in October had riled state media after he likened state-run banks to pawnshops.<p><p>The companies were given a month to conduct a self-inspection and publicly promise to curb anticompetitive behavior and follow Chinese laws on everything from data protection and taxes to speech.<p><p>According to a China scholar at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington
column29: China's leaders take very seriously having a subservient
column30: quiescent private sector.<p><p>On a call with analysts last month
column31: Martin Lau
column32: Tencent's president
column33: struck a conciliatory tone toward the authorities.He said that Tencent will be even more compliant."<p>

headline: <p>Facebook is preparing for the Chauvin verdict<p>
content: <p>"Facebook plans to limit posts that contain misinformation and hate speech related to the trial of the former Minneapolis police officer charged with the murder of George Floyd.<p><p>It also said it would protect members of Mr. Floyd's family from harassment and take down content that praised
column5: celebrated or mocked his death.We want to strike the right balance between allowing people to speak about the trial and what the verdict means
column6: while still doing our part to protect everyone's safety.<p><p>The Silicon Valley company has been criticized for its handling of sensitive news events.Last year
column7: online misinformation about voter fraud galvanized supporters of former President Donald J. Trump.<p><p>The Capitol building was occupied by supporters of Mr. Trump who believed the election had been stolen.The company displayed warnings on more than 150 million posts with election misinformation
column8: removed more than 120
column9: 000 posts for violating its voter interference policies and took down 30 networks that posted false messages about the election.The social network stopped Mr. Trump from posting on the site after the Capitol storming.The company's independent oversight board is debating whether the former president will be allowed back on Facebook and has said it plans to issue its decision in the coming weeks.<p><p>The company said it would remove pages and groups that violated its policy
column10: take down attacks against Mr. Chauvin and Mr. Floyd
column11: and label misinformation and graphic content as sensitive."<p>

headline: <p>After the app makes some changes
content: Parler can return to his phone<p>
column5: <p>"The Parler app was kicked off in January after tech companies said the network had not effectively policed content around the time of the Capitol insurrection.<p><p>The lobbyist said in the letter that Apple told Parler that it was welcome back because of the changes it had agreed to make to the app.<p><p>He said that Parler would return to the App Store when it submitted a new app.<p><p>Amazon stopped supporting Parler's social network in January

headline: <p>Less tech is the best for vaccine passports<p>
content: <p>"The On Tech newsletter contains this article.I have been reluctant to write about whether or not Americans might provide proof of vaccine against the coronaviruses.<p><p>It is a political
column5: cultural
column6: ethical and legal mess.If some places start requiring a vaccine passport
column7: it makes sense for them to do so in ways that win people's trust and don't ruin their privacy.Technology related to our health should be minimal.<p><p>Early efforts to create vaccine credentials
column8: like the Excelsior Pass in New York
column9: essentially create a replica of those state databases with information including your name
column10: date of birth
column11: address
column12: the batches of your shots and so on.It increases the risk of your sensitive data leaking out when you add multiple layers of technology into any system.It is expensive and complicated for everyone involved.<p><p>The difference is that the apps wouldn't be able to access your sensitive information.The data is sent directly from your phone to the state health records.He compared this proposal to paying for a sandwich with cash instead of a credit card.<p><p>The metaphor isn't perfect
column13: but it's useful.<p><p>Some of the organizations pitching vaccinationcredential technology
column14: including IBM and the airport screening company Clear
column15: are making a similar pitch that their technologies are as minimal as possible.<p><p>Tech companies
column16: states and others have tried to throw a lot of smarts at the problem.<p><p>Something has gone off the rails if you hear the word blockchain with vaccine credentials.The risk is that we get complicated
column17: potentially incompatible technology for people to provide proof of vaccination.What we really need is dumb technology that does as little as possible and knows as little about us as possible.How can we make it simple
column18: simple
column19: simple as opposed to what technology companies are doing
column20: which is to add more?<p><p>This is a nuanced and interesting interview with Dr. Arthur Caplan
column21: a medical ethicist
column22: about vaccination credentials.<p><p>Big Tech means fighting big governments: Governments around the world are trying to put limits on tech companies with an urgency and breadth that no single industry had experienced before.There is a common cause of government angst: tech companies' power.The machines that mix McDonald's ice cream and shakes are proprietary
column23: fragile and complicated
column24: and only approved technicians are allowed to fix them.<p><p>How do you bottle-feed a bunch of baby goats at the same time?<p><p>We want to hear from you.<p><p>Tell us what you think of the newsletter and what you want us to do.If you don't already have a newsletter in your inbox
column25: please sign up here."<p>

headline: <p>"No
content: Other People's Covid Vaccines can't change your menstrual cycle"<p>
column5: <p>"In recent weeks
column6: people who oppose Covid vaccinations have spread a claim that is not only false but defies the rules of biology: that being near someone who has received a vaccine can disrupt a woman's menstrual cycle.<p><p>There are at least three women with menstrual cycles impacted after having spent time with a vaccine person
column7: so it is impossible to experience any effects from being near a vaccine person.Different vaccines use different vehicles to deliver the instructions
column8: but the instructions are the same.<p><p>It's not possible to transfer the vaccine from one person to another.<p><p>Microorganisms spread from person to person by replicating.The vaccine ingredients can't spread because they can't replicate.<p><p>The vaccines stay in your arm and don't spread through your body.It is also not something that sticks around.It took a long time for scientists to figure out how to keep Messenger RNA intact
column9: which is one reason we have never had an mRNA-based vaccine before.<p><p>People who have Covid are the ones who shed virus.<p><p>If you want to prevent yourself from getting Covid
column10: the best way to do that is to get a vaccine.<p><p>It is not possible for these two events to be connected because one person's vaccine can't affect anyone else.There is a conspiracy that has been created to weaken trust in a series of vaccines that have been shown in clinical trials to be safe and effective.<p><p>Conspiracy and false narratives are dangerous and have nothing to do with science.This is theoretically possible
column11: and research is ongoing
column12: but anecdotal reports could be explained by other factors
column13: and no study has found a connection between the vaccine and menstrual changes.We are going to have a full moon tonight because I got vaccine today."<p>

headline: <p>"Don't ignore the threat of RansomwareIt is bad"<p>
content: <p>"The On Tech newsletter contains this article.Ransomware attacks can be devastating
column5: and they are only getting worse.<p><p>This form of cybercrime involves hackers breaking into computer networks and locking up digital information until the victim pays for its release.<p><p>Hospitals have had to turn away patients because of cyberattacks
column6: and a natural gas line was offline for two days last year.She told me that the U.S. government and individual organizations could do more to prevent it.<p><p>The root of the problem is that America has failed to invest in its defense.There has been a surge in attacks and more organizations are being targeted.The epidemic made things worse.<p><p>In the last few months in the United States
column7: gangs have hit big businesses
column8: schools and universities
column9: local governments
column10: hospitals and the police.They are getting bolder.A relatively new twist is criminals threatening to release organizations' data publicly if they don't pay.<p><p>The nurses said it was one of the worst experiences of their careers.<p><p>How can anyone justify hurting cancer patients or leaking photos of dead people?<p><p>I have no words for this that could be printed in a family newspaper.We are not acting like the United States is the most targeted country.We outline guidelines for companies and government agencies to prevent attacks.<p><p>There is a chance that the U.S. government could designate ransomware as a national security threat on par with terrorism.<p><p>Sanctions or restrictions on travel to the United States could be imposed on countries that are safe havens for gangs.That would force countries to take action against the criminals who are inside their borders.The Treasury Department has the power to prohibit victims from paying ransoms.<p><p>If companies
column11: government agencies and organizations required all employees and others who access their computer networks to use strong passwords
column12: password managers and multi-step authentication
column13: it would prevent them from being attacked.<p><p>They wouldn't have to pay to recover their own data.<p><p>I don't want to blame victims
column14: but why aren't companies and public agencies taking those protection measures already?American hospitals
column15: schools and governments are common targets because they tend to use older software with security holes that can't be repaired.The cyberattacks are going to get worse.Beijing could be the final arbiter of its tech industry because it is trying to force major technology companies to change behavior it considered anticompetitive.<p><p>Amazon
column16: which has been on a hiring spree
column17: will raise hourly pay for half a million workers.<p><p>We want to hear from you.<p><p>Tell us what you think of the newsletter and what you want us to do.If you don't already have a newsletter in your inbox
column18: please sign up here."<p>

headline: <p>Mr Beast wants to take over the business world<p>
content: <p>Jimmy Donaldson
column5: better known as Mr. Beast
column6: has over 90 million subscribers on his six YouTube channels.His videos have been watched 13 billion times.He became the most-subscribed YouTube creator in the country last year
column7: but he wants more.<p><p>MrBeast Burger has sold more than one million burgers and he has launched a mobile gaming app.He became an adviser to a financial network that provides business tools to online content creators in March.<p><p>He signed a deal with a company to distribute his content across a range of social media platforms.According to a report last year by SignalFire
column8: the creator economy is the fastest-growing type of small business.Mr. Donaldson is equally innovative and prolific in the experiments he is running to monetize his audience.His early videos and posts were criticized for being offensive.<p><p>Donaldson did not want to be interviewed.<p><p>A representative for him declined to address the working conditions at his companies but said of the videos with offensive content: "When Jimmy was a teenager and was first starting out
column9: he carelessly used a gay slur."Jimmy knows that there is no excuse for homophobia.The representative said that Mr. Donaldson has grown up and matured into someone that doesn\'t speak like that.<p><p>He posted videos of himself playing games like Call of Duty
column10: commented on YouTube drama
column11: uploaded funny video compilations and livestreamed himself reacting to videos on the internet.<p><p>He mastered the format that would make him a star: stunt philanthropy.<p><p>Mr. Donaldson filmed himself giving away thousands of dollars in cash to random people
column12: capturing their shock and joy in the process.The money initially came mostly from brand sponsorships.It turned out to be a perfect viral recipe that mixed money
column13: a larger-than-life persona and wholesome reactions.Millions watched his videos.<p><p>Mr. Donaldson had about a dozen people working for him in his small office.<p><p>He moved his companies into a bigger warehouse.His work force had grown to around two dozen
column14: people who worked for him said
column15: though it was hard to keep track because of an expanding group of contract production assistants who helped on video shoots.<p><p>Close friends acted as co-stars in his videos and developed followings off him.Mr. Donaldson expanded his business last year.Users were told to hold a finger down on the phone screen as long as possible in his gaming app.<p><p>Mr. Donaldson raised the prize to $100
column16: 000 after the app was a hit.<p><p>A new type of gaming controller was invested in by Donaldson.<p><p>MrBeast Burger
column17: which does not have a physical presence but allows diners to order food through delivery apps
column18: was started in December.In March
column19: Mr. Donaldson and the Creative Juice financial network introduced Juice Funds
column20: a $2 million investment fund that offers creators up to $250
column21: 000 in exchange for equity.Many fans praised him on social media for personally investing his money
column22: though the funding came from Creative Juice investors.Sima Gandhi
column23: chief executive of Creative Juice
column24: said that the company planned to work with many creators on Juice Funds and that Mr. Donaldson was the first.<p><p>They said that his demeanor changed when the cameras were not around.<p><p>Matt Turner
column25: an editor for Mr. Donaldson
column26: said Mr. Donaldson berated him almost every day.Mr. Turner said that Mr. Donaldson used to insult people with mental disabilities.Turner
column27: who did not grow up with Mr. Donaldson
column28: said that while his boss regularly featured his hometown friends in videos
column29: he had struggled to get acknowledgment.<p><p>Mr. Anderson said that Mr. Donaldson never worked for him.<p><p>He always wanted it to be the way he wanted it to be.Turner had the same experience.<p><p>He said that the kids don\'t know what they\'re saying.A student in college and a Mr. Beast fan said he was troubled by Mr. Donaldson\'s silence on online mob attacks.The behind-the-scenes turmoil has been imperceptible to those who watch Mr. Donaldson\'s videos casually.They became fans of Mr. Donaldson after watching his videos.<p><p>Mr. Donaldson planted 20 million trees to celebrate his 20 million subscribers.Mr started a YouTube channel called Beast Philanthropy
column30: which has grown to over 3 million subscribers.<p><p>Donaldson has 50 people working for him
column31: according to his representative.A core of a dozen writers
column32: editors and production assistants worked hard to pull off stunts like buying everything in a store
column33: giving people $1 million and only a minute to spend it
column34: building the world\'s largest Lego tower or buying an island.<p><p>According to SocialBlade
column35: Mr. Donaldson is projected to become the most subscribed creator in the world in the next year.<p>

headline: <p>The trial opened with a tour of the virtual world<p>
content: <p>Oakland
column5: Calif. is home to Cosmetics.There is a currency called V-bucks.There are virtual concerts.The popular gaming platform is more than just a game.Tim Sweeney
column6: chief executive of the company that created the game
column7: said in federal court on Monday that Apple wants an unfair cut of the money to be made in the game.<p><p>The legal arguments in the case center on the boundaries of the market the two companies are fighting over.<p><p>The case is about the broader app economy and that Apple has a monopoly with its App Store for iPhone users.<p><p>In a mostly empty courtroom in Oakland
column8: a lawyer from the law firm Cravath
column9: Swaine & Moore opened the case by showing a series of emails between Apple and Epic.Ms. Forrest argued that the tech giant created a "walled garden" that locked consumers and developers inside.<p><p>Ms. Forrest said that once Apple lured users and developers into its walled garden
column10: the garden gate was closed and the lock turned.She compared Apple\'s fees on in-app purchases for subscription services to a car dealership that takes a commission on gas sales.Weiss argued that the 30 percent commission was in line with industry standards and that if the requests were granted
column11: Apple would be forced to do business with a competitor.<p><p>The first day of the court fight over high-tech competition included in-the-weeds terms like hotfix.<p><p>The day began with a familiar experience.The start of the trial was delayed by 40 minutes because of technical issues with the hotlines set up for remote listening.<p><p>The judge said that it had been an adventure and that she would decide the case.Over the years
column12: app developers have complained about Apple\'s tight grip on its App Store and secretive ways it enforces its rules.Few have dared to speak publicly about it.<p><p>Sweeney dislikes the app stores control over access to apps and their impact on his metaverse vision.<p><p>Mr. Sweeney was so soft-spoken in his testimony on Monday that a court reporter had to ask for clarification on gaming and technology terms.He wore a suit and no cargo shorts.<p><p>Mr. Sweeney wore a clear face shield while testifying."I wanted to show the world through actions exactly what the ramifications of Apple\'s policy were
column13:
he said.<p><p>Doren asked Mr. Sweeney if he knew that the actions he took would cause Apple to remove his company\'s app from the App Store.He suggested that Mr. Sweeney was hoping that Apple would change its policy because of the popularity of the game.In the coming weeks, top Apple executives, including the chief executive, Tim Cook, and executives from Microsoft and Match Group are expected to testify.<p>
0,6,<p>On Wednesday, a Facebook panel will reveal whether or not Trump will regain his megaphone<p>,<p>The Oversight Board
column14: an independent and international panel that was created and funded by the social network

column17: and Facebook barred him.Critics are skeptical of the board's independence
column18: despite the fact that the panel's decisions are binding.<p><p>The panel is funded by a private company with a poor track record of enforcement of its own rules.<p><p>The company would not fact check political speech
column19: and even lies by politicians deserved a place on the social network because it was in the public's interest to hear all ideas by political leaders.The company said that Mr. Trump inciting violence and threatening the peaceful transition of power in elections was different."<p>

headline: <p>Stores are still importantWhere is Amazon?<p>
content: <p>"The On Tech newsletter contains this article.Amazon has been so successful in the last year that words almost fail me.<p><p>In the first three months of this year
column5: sales at Amazon's stores
column6: mostly from its Whole Foods grocery chain
column7: fell by 15 percent compared with the same period in 2020.The numbers from Amazon have gaping holes that make it hard to know what is happening.<p><p>Four years after Amazon agreed to a huge deal to buy Whole Foods
column8: we can tell that something isn't quite working.Why has one of the world's most ambitious and inventive companies mostly been a follower rather than a leader in one of the biggest spending categories for Americans?<p><p>It is considered to be at the cutting edge of innovation by consumers and Amazon competitors.That is not the case in groceries
column9: at least not yet.<p><p>The problem is that those numbers don't include the grocery orders that people place online and then pick up at stores or have delivered.An Amazon spokesman told me that adding up all of the ways that people are grocery shopping from Whole Foods
column10: including online ordering for pickup or deliveries
column11: shows that the company's sales have been increasing.<p><p>It is often a sign that the numbers aren't amazing that Amazon doesn't give specifics.Walmart's grocery sales increased by 9 percent in the year that ended on January 31
column12: but the company is uncharacteristically quiet about it.It shouldn't be happening
column13: given Walmart's huge lead over Amazon in grocery sales.<p><p>Many people tried grocery delivery
column14: which is not a good sign for Amazon.<p><p>Sucharita Kodali
column15: who studies shopping and consumer behavior for the research firm Forrester
column16: found that many people were eager to roam the grocery aisles again.<p><p>According to a recent report
column17: the majority of grocery sales in the U.S. happen in stores.Forrester found that many people have been discouraged by problems with online grocery shopping.Many companies
column18: including Amazon
column19: Target and Walmart
column20: offer online grocery orders from the regular store shelves.<p><p>Those in-store sales could bounce back as city dwellers near Whole Foods stores come back and as office workers grab prepared meals again
column21: but no matter what
column22: Amazon's Whole Foods sales are worth paying attention to.<p><p>Something is amiss in what has been 15 years of Amazon's mostly disorganized and unsuccessful strategy in groceries.Besides its still-unproven technology to skip the cashier lines at stores
column23: Amazon's big move in groceries seems to be opening a new chain in addition to Whole Foods.I remain interested in what Amazon does in groceries.<p><p>Jimmy Donaldson
column24: better known as Mr. Beast
column25: is trying to build a business empire that includes investments in other online personalities and lending his name to a burger chain.Taylor Lorenz wrote about the behind-the-scenes turmoil in Mr. Beast's inner circle and whether people with big online followings can also build sustainable businesses.<p><p>There are online self-help groups in India that have been questioned or shut down by the police.There is something in the air.<p><p>In wood.For real.<p><p>The Canadian logger was turned into a lumberjack TikTok star because of the lumber-related meme.We want to hear from you.<p><p>Tell us what you think of the newsletter and what you want us to do.If you don't already have a newsletter in your inbox
column26: please sign up here."<p>

headline: <p>The Amazon union drive was defeated by a wide margin<p>
content: <p>"Amazon.com Inc warehouse employees in Alabama were on track to reject unionization by a 2-1 margin with almost half the votes counted in an election seen as a potential turning point for organized labor.<p><p>The vote count will resume at 9:00 a.m.The U.S. labor movement has been trying to unionize Amazon

headline: <p>The letter X is changing the game for travelers<p>

headline: <p>There has been a surge of migrant children entering Mexico<p>
content: <p>"According to the UN Children's Fund
column5: the number of migrant children arriving in Mexico and hoping to enter the United States has increased ninefold from January to March this year<p><p>The number includes data from Mexico's National Migration Institute and other official sources

column8: which plans to spend $4 billion over the next four years on development programs in the region<p><p>The real child crisis isn't at the US border but in the poorer communities of northern Central America and Mexico"<p>

headline: <p>There is a hurdle in the Legislature when it comes to voting restrictions<p>
content: <p>A bill that would impose a host of new restrictions on voting in Florida passed a key committee in the State Senate on Tuesday after a fiery debate among senators and hours of citizen testimony opposing the measureThe bill was revised last week by Dennis K Baxley

column10: 000 votes<p><p>The successful election in Florida was the reason that Democrats

headline: <p>The authorities did not try to use the red flag law<p>
content: <p>The senior county prosecutor in Indianapolis said on Monday that his office never sought to invoke a law that could have prevented Brandon Hole from buying two firearms before he shot and killed eight people last week at a FedEx packaging warehouse<p><p>The tragedy of last week\'s mass shooting
column5: and the questions about missed opportunities in the months that led up to it
column6: has highlighted some flaws in the red flag laws that have been adopted in more than a dozen states<p><p>If Mr Hole had been subject to such a determination after his mother contacted the authorities in March 2020
column7: he would not have been able to legally buy two rifles<p><p>It is notThe authorities do not always have the tools they need to make the most well-informed decisions because of a number of loopholes in the law<p><p>Some people who have studied gun violence say that suicide prevention should be seen as the primary purpose of red flag laws<p><p>The courts have denied some petitionsThe targets have regained their ability to own weapons in other cases where authorities initially won restrictions<p><p>One man in the Seattle area who wrote violent messages online
column8: one of which was "Kill all women"
column9: got his guns back after arguing before a judge that the messages were jokes<p><p>He said that any law should be part of a larger framework to prevent gun violenceIt isn\'t a one-thing problem and it isn\'t a one-thing solutionOne of the oldest red flag laws in the country is Indiana
column10: named after an officer known as Jake who was killed in the line of duty<p><p>All but one of the eight petitions filed this year are still pending<p><p>According to police records
column11: Mr Hole\'s mother and sister showed up at a police roll call on March 3
column12: 2020<p><p>According to the chief of the Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department
column13: the mother told the officers that her son was contemplating suicide<p><p>The hospital stay for Mr Hole was measured by hours and not daysThe more well-known red flag laws
column14: which generally require a full court hearing and a judge\'s order
column15: could potentially have been a more useful tool in preventing Mr Hole from buying more gunsIt is not clear if this kind of law would have applied in Mr Hole\'s case
column16: but Indiana has no such law anywayThe family agreed to give up the gun after it was seized<p><p>There is a period of 30 days to comply with a subpoena<p><p>He said they were dealing with a 14-day time window<p><p>Losing the case would have required the police to return the shotgun they had seized
column17: even though the family had voluntarily forfeited itPeople who have been involved in domestic violence can be seen by the police<p><p>Mr Hole\'s case appears to have been prompted by his family\'s concerns aloneChief Taylor said that Mr Hole was not the one who told the police of his suicidal thoughts and that the officers who responded felt that she was believable enough to take immediate action<p><p>Mr Hole appeared to play down his intentions in police recordsIt would be difficult to prove to a judge that Mr Hole presented a serious riskHe said that there were other parts of the law that did not apply to Mr Hole<p><p>While her case was pending before the judge

column19: but it was far from perfect<p>

headline: <p>The network of Navalny is collapsing under Kremlin pressure<p>
content: <p>Navalny\'s associates said they were shutting down their nationwide network of regional offices on Thursday even as the imprisoned Russian opposition leader vowed in an online court appearance to keep fighting the "emperor with no clothes" in the Kremlin<p><p>Prosecutors want Mr Navalny\'s movement to be declared an extremistsThe aide to Mr Navalny said it was impossible to work under these conditionsThe demise of Mr Navalny\'s network of regional offices is the end of an era in Russian politics<p><p>Many of Mr Navalny\'s associates have been jailed or forced into exile

headline: <p>"There is an inheritance tax bill you can't keep up with"<p>

headline: <p>How it looks when families reunite is called joy

headline: <p>The police officer used his knee to pin down Mario Gonzalez<p>
content: <p>"One day before a Minneapolis jury convicted a former officer of murdering George Floyd
column5: police officers answering a complaint about someone loitering in a park in the Bay Area suburb of Alameda pinned Mario Arenales Gonzalez to the ground
column6: using their knees
column7: forearms
column8: and elbows<p><p>An analysis of body camera footage by The New York Times found that the April 19 death occurred after one officer appeared to keep his knee on the upper right side of Mr GonzalezThe city of Alameda said in a statement this week that it was committed to full transparency and accountability in the aftermath of Mr Gonzalez's death<p><p>A private law firm has been hired by the city to conduct an investigationThe situation was called a terrible loss of life by the police department<p><p>Ed Obayashi
column9: a California-based expert in law enforcement training and the use of police force

column12: not on Mr Gonzalez
column13: because he was bucking so fiercely on the ground<p><p>The death

column15: was described on Wednesday by civil rights lawyers and law enforcement experts as a reminder that police officers continue to use some of the same restraint techniques that led to Mr Floyd<p><p>Why are they still doing it?<p><p>The rush of business is what it isThe three officers who were put on leave did not know why they had to detain Mr Gonzalez<p><p>The footage shows that Mr Gonzalez was not a threat when Officer McKinley walked up to himI am going to check on you to see if you are okay<p><p>Officer McKinley asked Mr Gonzalez if he was thinking about hurting himselfMr Gonzalez

column22: pulling them behind his back to handcuff himHeavyset with thick arms

column25: the officers asked what to do next
column26: and decided to keep him pinned down<p><p>Mario!<p><p>The analysis of the body camera footage by The Times showed that Mr Gonzalez appeared to be on the ground for 5 minutes 5 secondsThe officers applied some form of pressure on his back for 2 minutes 50 seconds

headline: <p>"There is a debate over China's propaganda"<p>
content: <p>In China

column9: a popular social media service

headline: <p>"Some hospitals don't have enough Oxygen to keep patients alive"<p>
content: <p>"Large numbers of people around the world are dying because they don't have access to medical oxygen
column5: especially in IndiaOxygen makes up 21 percent of the atmosphere because tens of thousands of people are admitted to hospitals with Covid-19<p><p>Most of it is sold to industry by a few companies that capture and purify it in bulkMany poorer parts of the world lack the infrastructure needed to deliver or make use of the medical grade supplies those companies sell
column6: which are designed to be delivered via pipes to hospital roomsMany hospitals and patients in poor countries rely on the most expensive option: oxygen tanks that have become scarce in the countries hit hardest by the virus<p><p>Oxygen supply never rose to the top of the list<p><p>When lethal oxygen shortages hit northern Brazil
column7: Mexico and elsewhere early this year
column8: it became clear that what had been seen as a potential problem was becoming a dire emergency<p><p>The World Health Organization created an emergency task force on the oxygen shortage and called for money to address itIndia's official count of new coronaviruses infections jumped from an average of 11
column9: 000 a day in February to an average of more than 370
column10: 000 in the past week
column11: and experts say the true figure is far higher<p><p>In wealthy countries
column12: hospitals generally rely on tanker trucks to make bulk deliveries of liquid oxygen
column13: far denser than regular air
column14: that is stored in large containers<p><p>The most cost-effective way of supplying oxygen is through a system of pipes that draws out the gas and transports it to the bedsideIn just the last few weeks
column15: some of them have begun ramping up their production of medical gas by redirecting some from industry<p><p>India's government has ordered the producers there to temporarily direct all of their oxygen output to medical needs<p><p>It is the most expensive option
column16: but it is the only one available to many parts of the developing worldHospitals in poor countries should have PSA plants and the piping to go with them
column17: as demand for them has soared faster than manufacturers can produce themIndia's government plans to install equipment in hundreds of hospitals
column18: but that could take months<p><p>In India
column19: the government is using trains and even military transport planes to get oxygen to the sick<p><p>If enough money were available
column20: governments and international groups could have advance-purchase agreements with bulk suppliers
column21: and emergency stores of oxygen could be stationed in various parts of the world and deployed as needed"<p>

headline: <p>The names of mothers will be included in marriage records in England and Wales<p>
content: <p>Marriage certificates in England and Wales have traditionally left space for the names and professions of just one parent: the fathers of the couple tying the knot<p><p>The British government said that the change corrects a historic anomaly and is part of a larger change of how marriages are registered in the two nationsThe Home Office said that the changes are the biggest to the registration system since the Marriage Act came into effectThe final stages of legislation to include both parents did not come before Parliament until last month
column5: spurred by a larger bill that passed in 2019<p><p>The changes were welcomed by many in Britain<p><p>Some said they had used their mothers as witnesses to their marriage to get around the requirements and make sure that they were included on the certificatesShe said it sat so wrong that she willingly took part in the erasure of women<p><p>The modification comes as other official departments also attempt to reflect social change<p><p>The fee for changing gender in England and Wales has been reduced from about $195 to $5<p><p>Activists for LGBTQ had criticized the cost as a barrier for trans people looking to officially recognize their gender identity on a certificate<p>

headline: <p>I covered mixed martial arts<p>
content: <p>"Times Insider explains who we are and what we do
column5: and gives behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together<p><p>I had never covered a sporting event before and had never heard of mixed martial arts<p><p>It was a familiar feeling as a China correspondent for The New York Times focusing mostly on politics
column6: society and culture in the countryIn the last month
column7: I have written about Indigenous hunting practices in Taiwan
column8: a devastating train crash on the island's east coast and a bizarre propaganda musical about Xinjiang in China<p><p>My colleague Amy Chang Chien and I had just written a profile ofZhang Weili
column9: China's top mixed martial arts star and a prominent if reluctant symbol of women's rights in the countryIt made sense for me to cover the fight because it was going to be one of the main draws of the event in Florida<p><p>I didn't know the rules of the sport<p><p>With less than 48 hours to get up to speed
column10: I did a deep dive into The Times's past MMA coverage<p><p>I was familiar with some popular MMA websitesI learned that fights are not matches but bouts
column11: and that several bouts make up a card from the guidance sent by the deputy sports editor<p><p>I read up on the basics
column12: like the prohibitions on biting
